<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A Good, But Not Great Remake<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
It&#x27;s a tale as old as time...and this &#x22;live action&#x22; remake of the
beloved animated &#x22;Beauty and the Beast&#x22; from 1991 wants desperately to
pay homage to the original while adding its own spin. I will say up
front that I loved the original and even owned the CD of the Broadway
musical it spawned years later. This movie pulls from both as well as
the original story. Does it work? At times. I will break down this
review in three sections: Casting, music, and direction. Casting:
Seeing as I&#x27;m not really a Harry Potter fan, I can&#x27;t say I was all that
ecstatic with the casting of Emma Watson. The movie didn&#x27;t change my
mind much. She sang well, but didn&#x27;t do much else for me. Even her
musical numbers felt flat with little expression on her face or in her
body. Kevin Kline was excellent as her father Maurice even though his
part felt limited. The real star of this movie was Luke Evans as
Gaston. He was having so much fun and ate up every scene. The rest of
the top-notch cast were fine with what they had to work with. Music:
All of your favorites from the original are here (&#x22;Belle&#x22;, &#x22;Be Our
Guest&#x22;, &#x22;Gaston&#x22;, etc) and a few new songs added as well. I enjoyed
some of the new lyrics and arrangements that were added to the original
songs. Nothing was taken away from them, which was good. The new songs
were okay, but none will be as memorable as the originals. Direction:
Bill Condon is no stranger to bringing musicals to the big screen as he
previously directed &#x22;Dreamgirls&#x22; as well as &#x22;Chicago&#x22;. So it&#x27;s no
surprise that this movie feels much more like watching a Broadway show
than sitting in s movie theater. (One of my friends said the guy next
to him would applaud after each musical number) The big musical numbers
(&#x22;Belle&#x22;, &#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22;, and &#x22;Gaston&#x22;) were grand with extravagant
visual effects and fun extras. Unfortunately Mr. Condon still struggles
with is good CGI (he also directed the last two &#x22;Twilight&#x22; movies. For
this to be &#x22;live action&#x22; just about every scene was computer animated
in some way (and was blatantly noticeable). The beast, nor the
household items, ever had much real expression. The backgrounds were
clearly green- screened (George Lucas would be so proud). And the final
scenes at the castle were so dark, you could barely make out what was
happening between the beast and Gaston. The last thing I will mention
is I would not recommend this to young children. I&#x27;m sure there are
plenty of little girls (let&#x27;s just say 10 and under) who love the
cartoon are going to want to see it. But it&#x27;s too long (over 2 hours)
and at times can be too scary. My 7 year old got bored about halfway
through. Several other young movie- goers in the theater seemed to lose
interest at times as well. Overall, it was good but not great. I hope
they do better with &#x22;The Lion King&#x22;.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Very well-done live action remake to one of my favorite Disney animated classics<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Exceptionally well-done live action remake to one of my favorite Disney
animated classics. Great casting, well-acted, amazing CGI affects, and
memorable musical numbers. The story-line is pretty much similar with
the animated version, but with some nice background story additions
about Belle&#x27;s mother and the Beast/Prince&#x27;s father. Also liked the
linking of magical enchantress to the villager &#x22;outcast&#x22; commoner
Agathe. The 3 new songs &#x22;Days In The Sun&#x22;, &#x22;How Does A Moment Last
Forever&#x22;, and &#x22;Evermore&#x22; added nice depth and background to this
live-action version.The 2 acting performances which stood out were Emma Watson (Belle) and
Luke Evans (Gaston). They both brought their animated characters to
real-life as well as could be imagined. Emma Watson gave a charming,
intelligent, sincere, and radiant performance as Belle. She performed
her various singing moments admirably and with good emotion for a 1st
time singer in a movie. It would be hard to imagine another actress who
could have played this role of Belle as well as Emma Watson. She has
made a nice transition from her childhood acting role as Hermione
Granger in the Harry Potter movies to Belle in &#x22;Beauty &#x26; The Beast&#x22;.
Luke Evans gave an entertaining, profoundly over-the-top, and
eventually villainous performance as Gaston. His singing prowess and
theater background came through in his 2 musical numbers. Next to the
CGI driven &#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22; and &#x22;Evermore&#x22;, Gaston&#x27;s 2 musical numbers
were among the most memorable musical moments.The other supporting cast members, from Ewan McGregor as Lumiere, Ian
McKellan as Cogsworth, Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts, and Kevin Kline as
Maurice fit their roles very well and pitch perfect also. The only reasons I only gave the remake 9 stars out of 10 are the
Beast/Prince character and the ending felt a little rushed. As far as
the Beast/Prince, his performance felt a bit too understated and smug
at first compared to the animated version. His efforts to gain Belle&#x27;s
affection had more of a plan in the animated version than this live
action version. The one scene where this difference stands out is when
the Beast/Prince introduces Belle to his large library room. It is
different and not as planned compared to the animated version. Also,
would have preferred that the Beast had more human acting moments after
his transformation back to a Prince. Dan Stevens still gave a very good
performance as Beast/Prince, but just not up to the level of excellence
as the rest of the cast. This brings me to the ending, which felt a
little rushed. It would have been nice to extend the ending a little
bit longer to get to know the human version of the castle characters
after the curse was broken and their transformation back to human form
was completed. Minor criticisms, but very few movies can be
perfect...lol.Overall, great live-action remake by Disney. Well-cast, beautifully
performed, and expertly directed. After &#x22;Beauty &#x26; The Beast&#x22; and
&#x22;Jungle Book&#x22;, looking forward to more Disney live-action remakes. I
believe &#x22;The Lion King&#x22; is up next.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A decent adaptation that chooses to give a montage of the animated film<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Following the success of the live action versions of Disney animated
classics like Cinderella and The Jungle Book, we have arrived to one of
the big fish in the vault: Beauty and the Beast. Of course, this story
has been told numerous times before, but none is more popular than the
1991 animated version. Disney once again delivers a live action remake
of their animated film with a stellar cast and Bill Condon who is a
strong director. The results provide a good looking film with good
intentions, but choosing to simply retell the story instead of
providing new perspective.Good: The direction and production design is gorgeous. The look of the
castle, the design of the furniture, the costumes, and the sets all
looked wonderful. Even the CGI wasn&#x27;t too bad with the objects in the
castle. The songs that were in the original animated film are re- done
here with varying success, but still fun. The cast were well suited in
their roles with Luke Evans killing it as Gaston. Emma Watson was solid
as Belle although nothing fantastic. Kevin Kline actually delivers a
good performance her despite his limited role in the film. Josh Gad
does help give LeFou more depth in his character with his conflicts
with Gaston. Speaking of which, the controversial addition of LeFou
being gay bears little consequence in the story. Nothing in the form of
kissing or sexual innuendo that was blown out of proportion. An
addition, but nothing too in your face so this fighting is over
nothing. Bad: This film takes the beats of the animated film and goes through
them exactly how they were presented with little change. They do add
some additional scenes along with some new songs that don&#x27;t hit their
mark as much as I wanted them to because there are some interesting
ideas passed around in them. The singing is good for the most part, but
Watson&#x27;s voice does smell of tinkering that shows every time she goes
for the high notes. I think she can sing, but she&#x27;s not capable of
holding notes for a long time which shows in her singing. It hurts her
musical scenes which lessens the impact. I didn&#x27;t like the look of the
Beast here as they wanted to give him a more human face which defeats
the purpose of him looking beastly.Overall, I wanted to really like this movie, but it played it too close
to home with its interpretation and relied on replaying the old hits.
The new content added didn&#x27;t do much for me either so both methods just
couldn&#x27;t work. I liked the revamped songs from the animated film and
there are some performances along with beautiful production design and
cinematography. Worth a watch if you are a Disney fanatic, but I would
say the animated version remains on top.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Boring and the Bland<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Beauty and the Beast is another utterly pointless cash-grab of a
remake. While not a bad movie, it is nowhere near as good as the
original. Somehow, this film is nowhere near as emotional despite the
fact that it involves real tangible human beings instead of cartoons.
The new cast is hit and miss. Josh Gad and Kevin Kline provide some
much needed charm and levity to the film. On the flip-side, the leads
(specifically Emma Watson) are spectacularly underwhelming. Emma Watson
simply does not look, sing, or act the part. The movie plays like a
pale imitation of the original. Ultimately the whole thing is brought
down by the script. It is essentially the same script as the original,
but there are certain changes thrown in simply for the purpose of
change. There are multiple sub-plots added which just come off as
unnecessary filler. What makes matters worse, is that the film cuts out
important story beats from the original in order to make room for the
new unnecessary sub-plots. Other than some solid visuals and
performances this movie doesn&#x27;t offer much. Overall, Beauty and the
Beast (2017) isn&#x27;t good, and it isn&#x27;t bad. It&#x27;s just pointless.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>&#x27;Beauty and the Beast:&#x27; An Absent, Vague Reimagining of a Classic<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
&#x22;Beauty and the Beast&#x22; is a 2017 musical romantic fantasy remake of a
1991 animated film of the same name. It is directed by Bill Condon
(&#x22;Twilight: Breaking Dawn&#x22; parts 1 &#x26; 2) and is written by Stephen
Chbosky (&#x22;Perks of Being a Wallflower&#x22;) and Evan Spiliotopulos
(&#x22;Huntsman: Winter&#x27;s War&#x22;). The music is by Alan Menken (&#x22;Aladdin&#x22;);
the cinematography by Tobias A. Schliessler (&#x22;Dreamgirls&#x22;); the editing
by Virginia Katz; and the production by David Hoberman (&#x22;Monk&#x22;) and
Todd Lieberman (&#x22;The Fighter&#x22;). It stars Emma Watson (&#x22;Harry Potter&#x22;),
Dan Stevens (&#x22;Downton Abbey&#x22;), Luke Evans (&#x22;Clash of the Titans&#x22;),
Kevin Kline (&#x22;Sophie&#x27;s Choice&#x22;), Josh Gad (&#x22;Modern Family&#x22;), Stanley
Tucci (&#x22;The Lovely Bones&#x22;), Audra McDonald (&#x22;Private Practice&#x22;), Evan
McGregor (&#x22;Star Wars&#x22;), Gugu Mbatha-Raw (&#x22;Doctor Who&#x22;), Ian McKellen
(&#x22;X-Men&#x22;), and Emma Thompson (&#x22;Sense and Sensibility&#x22;). Filming began
May 18, 2015 in Surrey, England with an estimated budget of $160
million, and a box office totaling at $1.103 billion internationally.
It has a running time of 2 hours, 19 minutes (139 minutes), and a PG
rating for mild violence. Now to the review:Belle (Emma Watson) is a gorgeous, kind, and smart young woman living
in a small- minded village in France. Despite constant wooing from
village heartthrob Gaston (Luke Evans) Belle keeps her feisty
independence and devotion to intellect. Her father Maurice (Kevin
Kline) goes on a &#x22;trip&#x22; (Doing God knows what, that&#x27;s never really
explained), and she asks for a rose. Maurice ends up getting lost in
the woods, and comes upon a castle where, unbeknownst to him, a cursed
Beast (Dan Stevens) and his staff reside. Maurice is captured by the
enraged Beast, and Belle, learning of her father&#x27;s disappearance, goes
to the castle and trades her freedom for his. Slowly, Belle and Beast
fall in love, while a frazzled Maurice searches for help to rescue her.
He finally gains the trust and help of Gaston and his lackey LeFou
(Josh Gad). So here&#x27;s what I think it boils down to. Something as beloved and
treasured as &#x27;91&#x27;s B+B should not ever be made into a remake without
taking all possible precautions. You need a Belle who can sing and act,
a beast who looks fairly realistic, a CGI castle that actually looks
plausible, and you need an interesting and captivating script/plot.
Otherwise, the project should not be taken on.Obviously, this will be a huge box office hit. And I understand. No one
is immune to some nostalgia, especially from an amazing original
animated film. But I miss the times when cinema had standards. I miss
the clever and impactful films Disney used to make. If we are meeting
films like this with widespread approval, then what messages are we
sending for future Disney films?EDIT: I wanted to quickly type a little blurb on Watson&#x27;s Belle. Here
goes... As many of you may know, Emma Watson is a huge advocate of the
feminist movement. She is a UN Ambassador, and was fundamental in
releasing the HeforShe campaign. For this, I admire and respect her
(who wouldn&#x27;t). It&#x27;s truly inspirational to see young, influential
women like herself trying to make a difference. Bravo. Good for her. So
you can imagine, when Watson was announced as Belle, it was a huge deal
mainly because Watson is much beloved from her Potter days. In fact,
Watson revealed she had plans to renovate Belle and make her story a
more feminist inclined retelling. Here is Watson, when asked why her
Belle specifically, is a feminist:&#x22;So, we created a backstory for her, which was that she had invented a
kind of washing machine, so that, instead of doing laundry, she could
sit and use that time to read instead. So, yeah, we made Belle an
inventor.&#x22;Now, I guess one could say that that this is a slight improvement (no
matter how unnecessary) on Belle. But why? What more is being said?
&#x22;Hey, not only can she read, but she also can build things too! Now
that&#x27;s what I call a feminist princess!&#x22; But Belle was already a feminist princess. A bit outdated considering
our times, sure. But if you&#x27;re going around flaunting the term
&#x22;Feminist Belle,&#x22; then I expect more than one 1.5 minute scene where
she&#x27;s using her washing machine, and then a 30 second clip in which
that same machine is destroyed. God, what is your point? What more is
this bringing? What thought is this provoking? Now, I think the idea of revamping a feminist Belle is great. I do,
really. Watson had great intentions. But if this is all we&#x27;re getting,
then what&#x27;s the point if you&#x27;re adding so little?My Advice? Watch the original. 3/1030% F
<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Redundant, but what the heck.<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Upon viewing Jon Favreau&#x27;s Jungle Book (2015) for the second time, I
admired how far a departure it was from its Disney source material. The
pillars of familiarity were leaned upon but the films strengths were
drawn from some remarkable new ideas and execution. If Bill Condon&#x27;s
Beauty and the Beast (2017) can be admired for anything it is giving
the people what they want. Aside from a handful of new songs and
character tweaks, this new adaptation is almost painstakingly dutiful
to the 1991 Disney feature. There will be some, like me, who find it
all a little too redundant; but for the bulk of viewers the relentless
nostalgia won&#x27;t disappoint.There is no point in prefacing anything with &#x22;spoiler alerts&#x22;, as you
have already (ostensibly) seen this movie. Belle is the rural French
misfit in her small village. Beautiful, but &#x22;a funny girl&#x22; simply
because she thinks for herself. Emma Watson portrays Belle capably, but
without much range. Her opening number shows promise, hitting her
required pitches without unnecessary flourishes. She floats through the
lively town square in ennui. The long takes are well crafted and the
music plays like a sing-along, kids who know the words will make the
theater pretty adorable. Kevin Klein as Belle&#x27;s father (Maurice) is a
bit of a departure from the original. He is not the buffoonish cartoon,
but a more haunted widower. The Gaston role is filled with ease by Luke
Evans. He is a powerful singer and has the convincing swagger that
comes with the territory. His lacky, LeFou (Josh Gad) couldn&#x27;t be more
at home in the movie if he was actually animated. The issue with the
vibrancy of the setting is it does offset Belle&#x27;s dream of escaping the
&#x22;boring village.&#x22;Our first glimpse of the castle actually occurs in the prologue. The
arrogant and spoiled Prince hosts a glamorous ball that&#x27;s little more
than an embarrassment of decadence. A former plot hole is filled when
it&#x27;s explained that curse affects more than the castle. The local
villagers are cleared of any memory of the castle and its dwellers.
Years pass and Maurice has the misfortune of taking a fateful wrong
turn to the castle. From this point on the CGI absorbed setting just
doesn&#x27;t live up to the first act. Famous names voice the cursed
inhabitants, Ewan McGregor, Ian McKellan, Stanley Tucci, and Emma
Thompson. Once Belle arrives on the scene the &#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22; number
can&#x27;t arrive fast enough. Once it does, I&#x27;ll confess to being a bit
disappointed. As the song played I couldn&#x27;t help but have the Orbach
track playing in unison to McGregor&#x27;s and it became all too clear I was
watching a remake, and only a passable one.I would say that the film is entirely unnecessary, were it not for the
amazing title number. I was not sure who had voiced Mrs. Potts through
the film. As the vocals began for the &#x22;Beauty and the Beast&#x22; dance, I
would have put money on Julie Andrews. I was pleased to find that it
was Emma Thompson, every bit the equal of Angela Lansbury. Much has been made about certain political elements in the film, (I.E.
Homo-erogeny, diversity.) These are trivial. Had the film developed
these elements into more daring areas, it may have provided some very
welcome spice to the proceedings. This is a beautiful movie, but comes
up short in ways I might be too apathetic to articulate. I craved
something that the film may never have intended to provide. If I had to
boil this review down to one adjective I&#x27;d say &#x22;harmless.&#x22; Not a
glowing recommendation, but you&#x27;re likely to get exactly what you want
out of it&#x85; just not an inch more.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Moral of the Story: Marry for Money<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Beauty and the Beast is about a deposed slave-owning aristocrat who
imprisons a farm girl. She undergoes Stockholm Syndrome, identifying
with her captor, then proceeds to betray her village&#x27;s uprising and
reinstates the slave-owning prince to power by offering her hand in
marriage.Furthermore, Belle&#x27;s contempt for the provincial farming community and
their lack of refinement stems from vague memories she has of a more
cultured upbringing in Paris. When she later is shown a vision of her
childhood house and remarks &#x22;it&#x27;s so small,&#x22; this was a moment where
she could put it all together. The lack of refinement in the rural areas was due to brutal
exploitation which forced unmarried women to beg in the streets. It is
likely that the community&#x27;s surplus resources were taken by aristocrats
like the Beast, and used to fund his opulent palace. Thus, depriving
the farming community of leisure time and resources for education and
arts, which would have made them more sophisticated, meeting Belle&#x27;s
approval.It is also possible that Gaston&#x27;s intense desire to marry, which caused
his nefarious plot, may be linked to lev&#xE9;e en masse, a policy that
required conscription for all unmarried French men between 18 and 25.
So his patriarchal demands were a direct result of state policy to
benefit the aristocracy by providing soldiers to sacrifice their lives
in land disputes between inbred blue blood cousins.Then, this exploitation provided a concentration of wealth and power in
the city, which created the market for her father to pursue creative
employment rather than farm work. This also forced them into slums,
where squalor and poor public health systems lead to the spread of
plague, which is met with cold indifference by the doctor, indicating
lack of public health care as a source of Belle&#x27;s childhood trauma. All of this exploitation and upward wealth transfer made its way back
to the remote plantation of the Beast.When confronted with this inescapable logic, what does she do? She
decides to take the easy way out and enjoy the life of luxury, waited
hand and foot by Beast&#x27;s slaves, who feed her, clothe her, sing and
dance for her. A life she always felt entitled to, on part of her
feeling of superiority towards her provincial neighbors.The moral of the story is, marry for money, and ignore the suffering of
the poor. A terrible message for children.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Watered down, dull retelling of a timeless classic with questionable choices<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
When you take a timeless classic like Beauty and the Beast, one of few
animated films in history to ever to be nominated for best picture, you
know there&#x27;s going to be trouble at the idea of remaking an otherwise
flawless film (that&#x27;s not to say the original was one hundred perfect,
but near darn close!). But this is corporate Disney at it&#x27;s best,
trying to take something that was so special and rehash it for more
money instead of creating something entirely new. It&#x27;s no question that animation is an extremely difficult medium to
translate into live action. From a creative (non-financial) standpoint
it&#x27;s controversial on whether or not certain films should be done in
the first place, as they can be difficult to recreate...and this
version of Beauty and the Beast is the perfect example of this. With
questionable CGI, wooden leads, a weak script and an absolutely
atrocious rendition of Howard Ashman/Alan Menken&#x27;s beloved 1991 score
you have to wonder where Disney went wrong. What were they thinking?Let&#x27;s start off with the good: the production values of the film are
breathtaking, make no mistake. The sets and costumes bring Belle&#x27;s
world to life as if the animation was real. Belle&#x27;s village is nearly
an identical replica of the cartoon and Beast Castle&#x27;s looks absolutely
stunning. Every last detail from the way Beast&#x27;s servants are animated
to the transformation sequences look fantastic. The cast for the most
part is competently cast and acted, with Luke Evans hamming it up as
Gaston and Josh Gad stealing the show with Lefou. Kevin Kline brings a
charming new rendition of Maurice as do Ewan McGregor, Ian McKellen,
and Emma Thompson as Lumiere, Cogsworth, and Mrs. Pots respectively.
The script changes Disney made to expand the lore of the curse as well
as provide more backstory on Belle and the Beast were a welcome change.
Two new songs added to the film, &#x22;Evermore,&#x22; and &#x22;How Does this Moment
Last Forever?&#x22; are pretty, but almost make the film seem overstuffed.
Some subtle moments that were changed also may rub some the wrong way,
however. The script itself didn&#x27;t add anything new and at times felt
awkward.Emma Watson and Dan Stevens, unfortunately, are horribly miscast as
Belle and Beast. While Dan Stevens&#x27; vocal tone and inflections make a
decent Beast, there is absolutely zero chemistry with his costar Emma
Watson. On paper Emma is a wonderful choice for Belle. Not only does
she look the part but she is a wonderful role model for kids. Sadly she
merely does not have the acting ability to pull off Belle convincingly.
Belle here lacked the innocence and charm of her animated counterpart.
This especially shows in the scenes Belle has with Lumiere and the rest
of the servants. And the unfortunate mistake of having Disney decide to
keep the musical numbers from the legendary songwriting duo Alan
Menken/Howard Ashman is where the magic is utterly destroyed. Not only
is it absolutely unacceptable on Disney&#x27;s part to cast two people who
do not come from musical backgrounds to lead a musical, (for the most
part Beauty and the Beast is considered a musical) but it is also an
insult to Menken/Ashman&#x27;s legacy. If Howard Ashman were alive today he
would be outraged. A huge part of the original&#x27;s charm is the music,
and the soul behind the characters. Instead of hearing the powerful,
heartfelt notes and chords that describe Belle&#x27;s longing for change, we
hear soft, heavily processed, robotic renditions of &#x22;Belle&#x22; and
&#x22;Something There.&#x22; It doesn&#x27;t help Steven&#x27;s singing voice sounds like
an old fart. If Disney really wanted Emma&#x27;s face so badly they could
have at least dubbed her voice. While Gad, Evans, McGregor, and
Thompson pick up the slack a little bit in their musical numbers, the
music still falls flat. To add insult to injury the instrumental score
was almost entirely rewritten by Menken for this film. What happened to
those quiet, powerful rhythms when Belle is exploring the castle in the
West Wing, or the dramatic musical tension where Gaston and Beast have
their final battle in the original? All of that is gone. Minor nitpicks include the CGI; certain parts of the castle seem
engineered which was distracting, especially the scene with the wolves.
Subtle script changes also removed a lot of the charming little
character moments that were present in the original. Lumiere,
Cogsworth, Mrs. Potts and Chip unfortunately suffered the worse from
this with barely any screen time. Lefou and Maurice were actually an
improvement over their animated counterparts, which was great. The
changes they made with the enchantress were also wonderful.Beauty and the Beast overall is a watered down, dull retelling of
timeless classic. Now that&#x27;s not to say this film is completely
terrible; children and families who have never seen the original will
eat up the gorgeous cinematography, charming characters and the lavish
musical numbers. But for those who are classic-goers like me looking
for an imaginative retelling, Disney&#x27;s newest 2017 remake of Beauty and
the Beast clearly shows that it doesn&#x27;t hold a candle to it&#x27;s
predecessor. For those looking for a passionate, powerful, and
inspiring film, do yourself a huge favor and turn on the animated
version instead. On it&#x27;s own the film is below average, if not awful,
at best. 3/5 for an adaptation, 2/5 as a standalone.
<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Some Improvements Are Not Worth Making<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
It&#x27;s been a tale as old as time, a song as old as rhyme Beauty and the
Beast. It was one of the animated instant classics to trigger the
Disney Renaissance of the 1990s, defined an entire generation of Disney
fans, set off some of the most iconic songs ever to grace the screen,
was honored in several lists by the American Film Institute, was
preserved in the National Film Registry the second year it was eligible
(which is a huge deal), and was the first animated film in history to
receive an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture. &#x200B; So no pressure
or anything in remaking it, right?Many of us were worried that this remake would just be a line-for- line
remake of the original, but thankfully it&#x27;s not. Several updates to the
story are actually a strong improvement to fill in the problems with
the original. The whole village&#x27;s memory of the castle is erased by the
enchantress, a contrast made much more blaring by a cursed eternal
winter in the castle&#x27;s borders even while summer goes on in the
village.Belle&#x27;s father Maurice also has a more complex subplot that actively
engages both Gaston and LeFou, and he is motivated by his collection of
homemade paintings and inventions used to memorialize his family
legacy. This includes a backstory on Belle&#x27;s mother, even if it adds
virtually nothing to the plot.Other minor details are added to motivate Belle further, such as
teaching a younger village girl to read, only to be condemned by others
in the village. The parents will also enjoy this little detail: Gaston
is a former war hero, which gives his musical number a whole new
flavor. They also would find this new take on the Beast somewhat
compelling: he doesn&#x27;t even try to treat Belle decently as she first
comes into the castle. He just keeps her in the prison, only to be
moved into an appropriate bedroom without his consent or knowledge.There are plenty of other small plot holes from the original that are
explained here, as the characters make it blatantly clear. What I mean
is, it is done like this: one character asks a question we all asked
about the original, then another character simply answers the question.
Then the plot moves on as if nothing happened. So no high-class writing
to be found here.Although when taking the whole sum of the product into consideration,
the elements that remain the same compared to the original fall way,
way short. The director of this live action adaptation, Bill Condon,
who directed Dreamgirls and wrote the screenplay for Chicago, would
presumably know all about how to do a musical properly. Although his
skill is screaming to get out this time around, as nothing commands our
sorrow for his reimagining of the beloved characters. With the
exception of &#x22;Be Our Guest,&#x22; none of the musical numbers or recreated
scenes match the energy or creativity of its animated counterpart. I&#x27;m
not just referring to the fact that most to everyone&#x27;s singing voices
are hard on the ears, but mainly to the fact that everything is rushed,
especially the scene in the West Wing.If you think that you would feel charmed and nostalgic while watching
this, sorry&#x97;not happening. Maybe it works as a plot expansion of a
previously established story, but as a standalone you couldn&#x27;t help but
see the flaws. Belle even looks at the Beast more like she&#x27;s scowling
than like she&#x27;s captivated by him. Then with Gaston, he doesn&#x27;t feel
like a jerk at all, as in his first meeting with Belle, he doesn&#x27;t
chuck her book into the mud- but actually hands her flowers! Flowers!
From the guy we&#x27;re supposed to hate! It&#x27;s little details like this that
will halt any true joy or tears. But what else would you expect when a
remake is produced by a studio that cares more about social correctness
than casting actual French actors for a film set in France?Speaking of which, you may all be wondering at this point, &#x22;what about
the exclusively gay moment with LeFou? Should I worry about it harming
my kids?&#x22; Well, I can tell you this: You have absolutely nothing to
worry about. It&#x27;s a two second moment at the very end that is just as
subtle as it is super easy to toss onto the cutting room floor. In
fact, Josh Gad puts in just the right dose of humor and charm in his
interpretation of LeFou, and he actually can sing pretty darn well! So
you&#x27;ll end up loving his character by the end, whether or not you agree
with the homosexual lifestyle.Although if you ask me, this remake was never needed to be made. Yes,
it did satisfy many of the problems that people have complained about
for twenty-five years about the beloved animated classic, but it&#x27;s not
like this predictable fantasy is doing anything new or risky. If
anything, it&#x27;s just going to remind us of how much more moving and
charming the original is, and we can sleep easy at night now knowing
that some plot holes were filled without the animated film having to
explain it for us.Let&#x27;s just hope that the live action remake of Aladdin is not a total
waste of everything.
<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>When All is Said and Done, Everyone Deserves a Better Film Than This.<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
The highly anticipated release of the live action remake of Beauty and
the Beast had all the ingredients of a future classic. With the
animated film approaching it&#x27;s 25th anniversary, the hunger for
something like this is unfathomable. Yet, when the lights go on and the
credits roll, I was left feeling like I was swindled. The Bill Condon
film looks and sounds beautiful but the film is very thin in live
action form. Emma Watson is woefully underselling as Belle and Dan

remake.Overall, I was very disappointed by Beauty and The Beast. I thought
Bill Condon&#x27;s best work is left to be desired, the two leads are very

family movie that can entertain for a solid 2 hours but will do very
little outside of that. Is it worth going to see in the theater? No but
if you have kids, chances are you&#x27;re going to be dragged to it anyway
so just try and enjoy it for what it&#x27;s worth.

because I loved this film. Loved it. Look, I get all the criticism. I
was skeptical at first too; I doubted Disney wanted to accomplish
anything more than a mindless popcorn flick with this film, knowing
hordes of mindless sheeple would flock to the movie in droves because
it&#x27;s a remake of a classic. Pure capitalism is what drives the film
industry now, right? But the longer I watched, the more my breath was
taken away. Yes, I&#x27;m aware that it is pretty damn similar to the
original; but the lush beauty of the film has a sheer opulence to rival
Versailles. Complaints on the character designs notwithstanding, the
absolute beauty of the village and the castle blew my mind. A lot of
people are complaining about the lack of originality in this movie. And
to that I say...well, it&#x27;s a remake. I&#x27;m aware that remakes can
drastically differ from the original, and I have no problems with
filmmakers being inspired by another&#x27;s work. But still...it&#x27;s a remake,
guys. It wasn&#x27;t the script from the cartoon repeated verbatim; there
were some nice, subtle funny new bits thrown in, and I, on one hand,
adored the new songs in the film. However, I will concur that the
subplot regarding Belle&#x27;s mom is historically inaccurate and adds
nothing to the plot. But regardless, I think the film did a good job of
triggering nostalgia while adding its own little flourishes in. Acting
and performance wise, I&#x27;ve heard a lot of people complaining about Emma
Watson; yes, you can tell she&#x27;s not a professional singer, but I think
she did a perfectly fine job as Belle. The real standouts here are
Gaston and LeFou as portrayed by Luke Evans and Josh Gad. They are
absolutely hilarious and breathe new life into these characters, and
deserve an accolade of some sort just for making them likable alone.
Singing wise, yes, you can tell that most of the actors aren&#x27;t
professional singers; none of them were horrid, though. If that sounds
like faint praise for a score of ten, it&#x27;s because I legitimately don&#x27;t
believe &#x22;Emma Watson has a weak voice&#x22; negates the emotions I felt
while watching. If you just let yourself enjoy the renewed vitality of
these characters and their story, you&#x27;ll see how genuine the romance
feels, how gingerly the characters develop into something there that
wasn&#x27;t there before. Bottom line: it&#x27;s a beautiful story, that&#x27;s why it
worked in 1991, and that&#x27;s why it worked yet again in 2017. If
anything, this movie rekindled my admiration of the original, and I
plan on viewing it again shortly.Pros: you know what you&#x27;re getting. Even if you do believe it&#x27;s a
soulless money grab, the elegance of the music and the tenderness of
the story cannot be eliminated. Also, the CGI is gorgeous.Cons: Again, it IS a remake, and if that bothers you, stay away. The
character designs of Cogsworth, Lumiere, Mrs. Potts, etc didn&#x27;t bother
me as much as others but definitely not as iconic as original. And yes,
Emma Watson is no Paige O&#x27;Hara when it comes to singing. That may be a
big deal for some people.In conclusion: Basically, this movie is the film equivalent of someone
rewriting your favorite book to be more eloquent, refined, and lavish.
Everything is bigger and bolder, but it&#x27;s still not the original.
You&#x27;ll probably still prefer the original, but you may return to the
remake every now and then for a renewed view of the story, that, who
knows, may make you appreciate it even more now.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Lacks magic<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Before entering theater, I knew Emma Watson looked the part. Belle
means beauty, and she certainly is that. With a movie that&#x27;s highly
concerned with pageantry, her looks are especially important. More so
than simply supplying the necessary beauty to play Belle, she has the
right look. She conveys intelligence, genuine concern, and a longing
for more. It comes from her eyes. They tell her story. She expresses
her thoughts and feelings clearly in every moment without saying a
word.For the most part, I could take or leave the live action Disney
revivals. This one felt like it had more promise to me, and a large
part of that came from the apropos casting of Watson. As it turns out, she delivered. She does far more than look that part,
she acts and sings it too. For anyone wondering, it really is her
singing. Unfortunately, she and the other actors pre-recorded their
vocal performances, which were subsequently dubbed over the visual
scenes. That makes for the song and dance displays ring just a bit
false, compared to the sincerity of those in La La Land. Granted, I
understand that complaining that a movie doesn&#x27;t live up to the
standard of another movie that won six Oscars, is beyond finicky. If you were worried that the new voices wouldn&#x27;t do justice to the
originals, rest easy. Every singer delivers, especially Watson. What a
voice she has. Who knew Hermione had golden pipes? The film doesn&#x27;t wait long to unveil the real-life Belle&#x27;s talents. She
flexes her performing muscles as she glides her way through the quaint
village brought to life. Everything seems great, just a little long. And that&#x27;s the movie&#x27;s
glaring problem&#x97;it&#x27;s too long. The filmmakers took the original&#x27;s tight
1 hour 24-minute runtime and ballooned it to 2 hours and 9 minutes.
Even Emma Watson&#x27;s charm can only last for so long. I&#x27;m not saying the
movie needs to trim some fat, but there&#x27;s no way it would fit in
Belle&#x27;s dress. Thank you, thank you. I&#x27;ll be here all article. As much as I&#x27;ve raved about Watson&#x97;and I strongly believe she deserves
all the praise&#x97;the rest of the movie doesn&#x27;t quite make it. At times,
the spectacle wore off and I just felt bored. There were a few too many
songs, and a few too many verses in some. I don&#x27;t remember how long the
original songs were, but I know that I never felt bored listening to
them. For all the glamour and loveliness, something was conspicuously absent.
The movie lacks magic. None of the songs bombed, but they didn&#x27;t
exactly floor me either. Another issue arose from the added scenes. I understand the desire to
show us Belle&#x27;s mother and the Beast&#x27;s parents. Many children&#x27;s movies
omit parents, with the implication that they died, and that&#x27;s it. An
illumination of why the Beast (a prince at the time) so rudely turned
away the stranger worked fine. But was it really necessary? Personally,
I never had any trouble believing the spoiled prince angle. The
dastardly daddy reveal didn&#x27;t add much. Perhaps it was intended to give viewers more sympathy for the Beast.
Meh. He earned my sympathy when he showed his kindness to Belle. I
always thought that was the point. The enchantress cursed him for
treating people poorly. That was his issue, not his dad&#x27;s. The
insertion of the dad story makes it seem like the Beast&#x27;s reprehensible
behavior wasn&#x27;t his fault. I didn&#x27;t like that implication. I was disappointed to see a few missed opportunities with the minority
characters. A word of advice: don&#x27;t bother including a black person as
the bookkeeper if he doesn&#x27;t have a chance to do anything. He&#x27;s used as
a showpiece. Nothing more. That&#x27;s not progressive casting; it&#x27;s
condescending. Sadly, the movie&#x27;s usage of gay characters felt even more insulting.
Including a gay character is fine, even better than fine, if the
character is represented appropriately. In this case, appropriate
simply means not in an overtly theatrical and effeminate manner. The
whole stereotypical portrayal was annoying. I&#x27;ll end on a high note. Credit must be given to the unimpeachable Emma
Thompson, Stanley Tucci, Kevin Kline, Ian McKellen, and Ewan McGregor.
They performed admirably. Future live action Disney films, should learn from Beauty. Casting is
vital and so is keeping the runtime reasonable. Forever can spare a
minute, but I don&#x27;t have that much time.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Tale as Old as Time, Review too Old to be Timely<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
I was out of the country during Beauty and the Beast&#x27;s opening. At the
time I could care less, now I am a bit disappointed. There is no chance
this review will scale the mountain of 600 more timely critiques. I&#x27;m
not gonna get a single view. Back then I did not care, I was more
interested in the reaction than the film itself. I already assumed the
critical consensus would be mildly positive, the only question
remaining was if audiences would be tired of a remake. Well, B&#x26;theB
made budget on first weekend, so expect Disney live action remakes in
the future. Still, popular pundits were unhappy. Beauty and the Beast
was heralded as a pointless remake of a classic. Even as I wandered
Shibuya ward with the soundtrack playing in the streets, I resolved to
skip the film after returning stateside. Weeks later, I wake up to find
my younger siblings have made plans to see a movie and that I am
coming. So here I am, pleasantly surprised.You&#x27;re a crusty bunch denizens of the internet. I, like you, agree that
there is an increased burden of proof for remakes. However, many of you
must have gone to the theater convinced you were going to have a lousy
time. Beauty and the Beast is a tale as old as 1757 with films
adaptations released around the globe since 1946. Does this retelling
innovate and drive the narrative to new heights? Absolutely not, but I
will claim that this iteration is entertaining and does enough to
justify its existence.The story and most songs remain the same. It&#x27;s not a shot for shot
remake, but if you had any problems with the animated classic, I doubt
they went anywhere. Personally, I still think the first song &#x22;Belle&#x22;
makes the title character appear as a brat. Does this immaturity
validate Belle&#x27;s growth and some character arch? Honestly, it has been
two films and I am still not sure. Additionally, the Beast is not ugly.
This conforms to the axiom that protagonists can never be hideous. It
is an ongoing problem that has existed since the &#x27;46 version. No
serious sins here. If you enjoyed the animated edition and are
unallergic to a flagrant derivation there is nothing at the heart to
despise. The additional 40 minutes of runtime is spent on a couple
songs, a bit more Belle backstory, and most conspicuously some
dimensionality to antagonist Gaston and his henchman Lefou. These
clowns were pretty forgettable. Devoting additional time to expand
these characters seems like a solid investment. Gaston&#x27;s sick
egocentrism and the yielding but aware Lefou are a worthwhile comedic
duo. Unfortunately, the cornerstone of Beauty and the Beast is also the
best argument for why the film should not exist. Emma Watson cannot
sing. Her voice is excruciating enough to eject you from the world and
back into your seat. Thankfully Belle does not participate in every
song. Watson&#x27;s acting between numbers is practical, but this is still
awful casting. I don&#x27;t think any more thought went into this decision
beyond that a 160 million dollar picture needs a 16 million dollar
face. Particularly painful is how easily this problem could have been
fixed. The technology has existed for nearly 100 years. Dub her. Bigger
actresses with better voices have been dubbed throughout Hollywood
history and got over it. You think the sounds of rattling carts and the
clomping horses were made by what you see on the screen? Movies are
illusions.Rant aside, I did enjoy Beauty and the Beasty. Beyond Watson&#x27;s voice
(okay I&#x27;m done now), is a lavish world. Fantasy, medieval, French. The
budget did not wither away here. Every set is gorgeous and half the
songs have 100s of elaborately choreographed extras. And the character
design. Animation was once the only possible medium to realize Mrs.
Potts, Lumiere, Cogsworth and Co, but now modern CGI is more than up to
the challenge. Trailers do little justice. You certainly have never
witnessed anthropomorphic furniture/dishware like this before. I never
thought &#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22; would be matched in a remake. Too the purists I
just insulted, maybe the original still remains supreme, but the fact
they are comparable suggests this reimagining is worth your time. It&#x27;s
the same sense of bedazzlement. That feeling is worth more than
original story. Beauty and the Beast only marginally expands character
and narrative, but this potential shortcoming is compensated with
visual ambition.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Try the grey stuff it&#x27;s delicious<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>

exploration of the Parisian windmill. Not everything necessarily needs
explaining within a film, and it almost felt as if the writers assumed
the audience was a little dumber than they actually are.One aspect of this film that drove me crazy was the visual effects.
Don&#x27;t get me wrong, there moments where I was very impressed by some of
the lavish effects. That being said, there were many times it was just
plain overkill. The Be Our Guest sequence featured far too many
flashing colors that made me think I was developing either ADHD or
epilepsy. I felt the computer graphic image rendering to be nothing
more than sloppy. the wolves in the movie made me wonder how any
computer artist could think that the work on them was remotely good
enough to put on the screen. That is how fake and unrealistic they
looked. I found big problems also with the design of the Beast. When
doing my research, I found that director Bill Condon wanted to create
the Beast with skilled makeup rather than CGI. However, Condon&#x27;s
request was overpowered by the studio heads in charge of the film, I
wold have much rather had a practical made Beast because his face was
at time frighteningly terrible. I gave praise to Logan&#x27;s visual effects
yesterday, and how well they were done. Beauty and the Beast brought
back to why I hate bad CGI more than nearly anything else in film, as
it can ruin so much within a singular movie. Finally, some of the
interactions between the furniture and the live actors felt clunky to
me as well. Many shots in the film had me question director of
photography Tobias Schliesser&#x27;s credentials as someone they did not
pick up off the street on the day production began. Many of the
pullback shots were so out of focus of the characters that you could
hardly see the character singing. Seeing as Beauty and the Beast is the
most expensive musical ever made, I truly believe they should have put
more time and effort into the visual effects.A major criticism of the film came in the casting of the actors, and
their inability to sing or fill the roles of the original voice actors.
Here&#x27;s the deal. Voice actors only have to worry about their voice.
That is the only thing they have to contribute to a film. Of course,
their voices are going to be better than live action actors, who have
many more dimensions to their performances. Yes, many of the actors in
Beauty and the Beast are not trained singers by any means sans Audra
McDonald. However, they give very solid performances of the songs.
Original songwriter Alan Menken even wrote some new songs for the live
action film. Are they slightly forgettable? Yes. However, they are
decently enjoyable tunes. The original songs have stood the test of
time of the past twenty-five years. They are bound to be more memorable
songs. Much of the casting was pretty spot on, in my opinion. Emma
Watson did a wonderful job exploring the feministic side of Belle,
showing the characters quiet strength in not only her acting but vocal
performance. There was no performance I think in the film that really
held it back. I still wish Jean Dujardin was cast as Lumiere over Ewan
McGregor, but you can&#x27;t always get what you want. Josh Gad is once
again a scene stealer as the more flamboyant model of LeFou. Also, if
you cannot handle a homosexual subplot for not even four minutes of a
film, you should not see movies. The &#x22;gay Lefou&#x22; storyline was blown so
far out of proportion by the media that you hardly even recognize it in
the film.Not enough praise is given to the technicians who create so much of the
films we see and get so little of the credit. The same goes for Beauty
and the Beast. The set design and costume design was lavish and
distinguished, and should definitely be recognized by The Academy for
Oscar nominations.Beauty and the Beast has moments where its brilliance shines through.
However, many parts of it feel clunky and too in your face. Overall, it
is an above average musical that is enjoyable throughout. If you must
compare it to the animated class which it is based, I give you this
shocking thought: Remakes are very rarely better than the original, and
this film is absolutely no different.Score: (7/10)

There are a plethora of one- and two-star reviews for this film on

that many people were entertained.That does not mean, however, that the film is perfect or that it could
not be better.The story is about the transformative power of love. Being a musical,
the viewer should expect romance and music. The music is an established
commodity. But how does the film realize the characters, the story, and
the action?I enjoyed Emma Watson as Belle. Her singing voice is more than
satisfactory and her acting fits the character. The other primary
character--the Beast--is more problematical. His CGI face takes the
viewer away from the action and disconnects the two romantic leads.
Also, the movement of the Beast sometimes looks weightless, as if the
he does not have a large and ponderous presence, which undercuts the
menace he is meant to project.I enjoyed the scenery and I think the camera work was very well done. Being a Disney fairy tale, we expect more than music and romance; we
expect enchantment. The overall effect of the film is enchanting: the
depiction of the town of Villaneuve, the renderings of the interiors,
the Beast&#x27;s castle, the landscapes, and the music, of course. There are
genuine moments that tug at the heartstrings, that jerk at the tears.The Beast&#x27;s facial CGI impacts the emotional content of his scenes
somewhat, but the film still delivers the Disney moments of heartbreak
and resolution.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Improvement on the Cartoon Version<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
As much as I love the cartoon version of this movie from my childhood,
it is full of plot holes and unanswered questions. The new Beauty and
the Beast did a great job addressing the plot holes, giving all the
characters more depth, and expanding on secondary stories. I appreciate
the detail and thought that went into the scenery and animated
characters. They conveyed the desperation of the cursed castle staff by
having their faces look less like people and more like the objects they
were turned into. They are essentially dying and very close to losing
their remaining human characteristics. They clearly steered more toward
progressive moral themes. The cast was more culturally diverse, La Fou
and another villager are (albeit subtly) gay, and they better
emphasized Belle&#x27;s positive traits despite adversity and social
rejection. I think they chose Emma Watson to get away from the Disney
princess stereotype. Don&#x27;t listen to other reviewers. Go see it, and
don&#x27;t go in expecting to see the old cartoon version.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Better than Expected<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Growing up watching Disney movies and being a huge fan of the original
cartoon of Beauty and the Beast, I went into the new live- action
remake with an open mind. And I was pleasantly surprised with the movie
and ended up thoroughly enjoying it. The movie does a wonderful job at filling in holes of the plot missing
in the original. It turns the story into something of more meaning,
rather than two people who fall in love. Belle&#x27;s sense of independence
and wonder and the emotional struggle the Beast faces are more
relate-able in the remake with live actors. Emma Watson&#x27;s performance as Belle is great, even with the somewhat
auto-tuned singing. Her interpretation of Belle showcases the
independence and charisma that the original character has. Dan Stevens
performance is equally as good. In my opinion, the best part of this movie is the directors
interpretation and writers addition of many scenes that fill in plot
holes. There is more background knowledge given than the original story
line, making it different and more realistic. Overall, worth your time to see.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A waste<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Despite the great amount of work that went into this remake, I am
having a hard time seeing as anything but a cash grab. The story really
lent itself better as a cartoon. It&#x27;s a story wants to be friendly and
light-hearted with talking furniture characters that seem more like
people than actual furniture. It seemed like attempts were made to give
it the same endearing qualities as the cartoon like the Be Our Guest
number and the playful furniture characters, but these did not blend
well with the dark color scheme, making the castle in complete
disrepair and in a perpetual winter, and other attempts at heightened
drama.There are a number of reasons for re-making a movie, but I really don&#x27;t
think this one was warranted. The primary issue with re-making this
particular Disney classic is that the original movie was pretty good. I
do not get the sense that any Disney fans wanted to see a live-action
reboot, and the cartoon only came out about 25 years ago and does not
feel like an old movie yet. Also, there was nothing terribly new that
was brought to the story. There were a couple new elements, namely a
subplot involving Belle finding out how her mother died and the notion
that the majority of the village is gullible and unintelligent, but
none of these things contributed in any way to the larger story. On the
whole it was the same movie done in CGI and green screen sets instead
of cartoon.In a theme and plot sense it was quite clunky. The cutting between the
different plot lines and characters did not feel well-timed to me, and
perhaps if I cared to look back at the exact sequence of the movie I
would know why. The main thematic point of the movie seemed to be
missed a bit. What makes Beauty and the Beast a &#x22;tale as old as time&#x22;
is that it&#x27;s the story of one person bringing out the kindness in
another and proving that anyone can rise above their external ugliness
with inner goodness. The scenes in which Belle and the Beast grow
closer to each other were, in my opinion, the best in the movie; but I
feel like there should have been one or two more of them so that their
relationship was stronger by the time they had to part ways. Having a
bunch of the villagers be connected to the servants of the castle was
just another forced and unnecessary element to cap it off.I was not at all impressed with the distribution of acting talent. None
of the actors did a bad job, but lower-caliber actors could have
delivered equally good performances. In that light, hiring such a
star-studded cast seems like it was just a way to get more money.
However, I must say that Luke Evans and Josh Gad made a good Gaston and
LeFou duo. This was diminished to a degree by nearly everything that
LeFou did or said point not so subtly to his being gay. Having a Disney
movie feature a gay character is fine at face value, but I don&#x27;t think
they pulled it off well here.Overall, I cannot recommend seeing this. There is nothing here that is
better than the original cartoon, even in a visual sense. I went to see
it because I was curious to see how Disney would reinterpret a classic
story, but there was not much to see. If this is how the upcoming line
of Disney re-makes are going to be, I will not bother seeing them
because the people in charge of the story do not seem to care about
making a quality movie. Overall Rating: 6.2/10
<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Mixed Feelings<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Before I start this review, I have to preface it by saying that I am a
huge fan of the Disney version that was released in the 90&#x27;s, so that
may have had a bearing on what I thought of this one.I have nothing against Emma Watson, and though I&#x27;ve never seen her in
anything else so I can&#x27;t testify to her acting ability, I thought she
was totally wrong for the part of Belle. She seemed to have only two
facial expressions: &#x22;Something stinks,&#x22; and &#x22;Something stinks, but I&#x27;m
going to smile through it anyway.&#x22; Some of the most emotional scenes
lacked the power to move me because I couldn&#x27;t get past how bland she
was.Something that really bugged me was the quality of the CGI. It wasn&#x27;t
just the enchanted castle staff, either, although seeing them brought
to life from their cartoon form was a bit jarring and creepy at times.
I was sorely disappointed in the appearance of the Beast. It seemed to
me that they tried to make him look too much like the cartoon version,
and it didn&#x27;t translate well into a real-life CGI look. All I could
think about every time he was in a scene was how off he looked, so much
so that it was distracting.There were some things I really enjoyed, like the fact that they kept
the original songs and even added some new ones. The &#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22;
sequence was particularly gorgeous, and I thought they did a fabulous
job bringing that scene to life.I like that they explained some things that weren&#x27;t explained in the
earlier cartoon version (like what happened to Belle&#x27;s mother, why they
left Paris, why the Prince was so awful in his prior human life, and
why no one seemed to remember the castle and its inhabitants). Luke
Evans was brilliant as Gaston, and they couldn&#x27;t have picked a better
LeFou than Josh Gad. The rest of the all-star cast (including Stanley
Tucci, Ewan McGregor, Ian McKellen, and Emma Thompson, just to name a
few) were outstanding in their roles as usual, but I do feel like Kevin
Kline was underused just a bit as Maurice.In all, it was a decent movie. Because my expectations were high, I was
a bit disappointed, and I can&#x27;t say that it&#x27;s one I feel like I need to
see again or add to my collection. But if you&#x27;re looking to be
entertained and dip a toe into nostalgic feelings, you&#x27;d probably enjoy
it.

that he feels guilty about having kept Belle from saying goodbye to her
father, he gives her the library etc.You really see his sweet side.

along the lines of &#x22;you can&#x27;t have it if you want whatever&#x22;. There
isn&#x27;t any reason for Belle to fall in love with him. The songs are
great and creative, especially Be Our Guest, but the new added songs
are dull and forgettable. The magic book was so pointless, it added
nothing to the story, in fact it created a small problem. When Belle
sees her father in the magic mirror, she runs off on the horse, but if
the Beast had the book which could take them anywhere, why would she
run all the way home? At least if she did that we wouldn&#x27;t have to sit
through the Beat&#x27;s song. I was disappointed with the dance scene, there
is a great part in the original where the &#x22;camera&#x22; pans down from the

disappointed that they didn&#x27;t include that famous shot. Again the dress
was a let down. I think the cast was great and all the voice actors did a great job!

routine in the cartoon. Also, when Beast transforms back into the
Prince, she&#x27;s just stood watching with a face like Kirsten Stewart,
she&#x27;s not really in awe or surprised that this is happening right in
front of her eyes. The cartoon is so bright and vibrant, it&#x27;s a wonder
to watch. This however, the colour palette was great for the first 20
minutes, but it was really dull for the rest of the movie, which I know
they wanted to make a &#x22;darker&#x22; version but I don&#x27;t think it really

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Autistic Reviewers Opinion Of This Movie.<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
As you are all aware Disney is rebooting all of its cartoon classics
and bringing them to life. The last one they rebooted was &#x22;the Jungle
Book&#x22; and that was so close to perfection. Sadly Beauty And The Beast
is a downfall from that. Jay And Nick (The Autistic Reviewers) will
start off this review by starting out with the bad and then ending with
the good. We always like to leave on a positive note! The Bad: There
are some horrible moments of CGI such as The Beasts face, the wolves
and Lumiere (in some scenes). The face of the Beast was just lazy.
Don&#x27;t think it had anything to do with the CGI...after all if Peter
Jackson&#x27;s 2005 version of Kong can look so real there is no reason that
The Beasts face could have been done the same or even better. The eyes
of the beast are also a problem. The eyes just don&#x27;t go with the CGI
face. You could either make the CGI better or just put a guy in a
costume. Lumiere (Ewan McGregor)and Cogsworth (Ian Mckellen) were
completely miscast. They didn&#x27;t capture the charm and humour the
original Lumiere and Cogsworth did. Audra Mcdonald who plays Madame
Garderobe was annoying as hell. In fact without going too far into the
voice cast just didn&#x27;t capture the heart nor the charm of the original
voice actors did with these characters. One of the biggest complaints
of this movie was casting Emma Watson as Belle. She just seemed
completely fake and kept looking away from the camera all the time as
if she was saying to the director &#x22;Am I doing this right? Am I doing
this right? Am I supposed to feel this way?&#x22; We always pictured someone
like Emma Stone or Rachel Mcadams playing someone like Belle. One other
big complaint is the director. The direction was awful. It felt like a
Twilight movie, and looking at the directors history of directing he
did, in fact direct the finale 2 Twilight Movies. It just did not fit.The good: The singing and the soundtrack was really good. It had songs
from the original movie and even 1 or 2 extra songs thrown in there for
entertainment purposes and it does work. Luke Evans as Gaston was the
perfect choice. He relive Gaston not only as a bully like he was in the
original, but also as a murdering, short tempered man. Josh Gad as
Lefou was also another good choice for casting. Him and Luke Evans
looked like they knew what they were doing and were having great fun
bringing their characters to life. More good news is that Emma Thompson
(who plays Mrs. Potts) was the perfect choice to play her. She was he
only voice that was convincing and her singing was really good.Verdict: With a better director and a better actress to play Belle and
many others this film could have been saved and made into an excellent
reboot like The Jungle Book, but sadly it didn&#x27;t end up that way. The
Autistic Reviewers give this 2/5 stars. 5/10. Check us out on facebook
and Instagram!

exchange with Ian McKellen&#x27;s Cogsworth brings a lot of humor in their
relationship. I also really enjoyed Dan Steven&#x27;s performance as the
Beast. Singing in the beginning of the film is a little bit of a turn-off. Not
because the actors couldn&#x27;t sing, but it&#x27;s one number after another,

temporary. Some of the actors are kinda there without much to do,
despite some amusing moments, like Kevin Kline, Stanley Tucci, Audra
McDonald, and Gugu Mbatha-Raw. The romance is solid. It never felt too over the top, and the chemistry
for the most part was there. I believe making people laugh and
showcasing romance is something hard to convey for any movie. Beauty &#x26;
the Beast does a commendable job at it, however while I never felt like
Belle and Beast&#x27;s relationship felt force, I wish that a little more
was given to them. The film does showcase their bonding, but most of it
are montages. Everything set up for their romance was just almost,
almost executed with perfection. I also wish I got to see more out of
Dan Steven&#x27;s Beast as well. The film hits in high gears once the film
introduces him. Special effects and production design are first rate. Yes there are
moments where you can tell it&#x27;s CGI, but it&#x27;s not that noticeable that
it&#x27;s going to distract you. Costumes are fabulous too look at and the
actors are well lit. Director Bill Condon does an excellent job
showcasing the fantasy land, it&#x27;s visually pleasing and enriching. The
ball-room dance sequence with Beast and Belle is done with justice too.At times Beauty &#x26; the Beast can feel cluttered and overproduced
eye-candy, but the film is a very faithful adaptation of the animated
film. Aside from a little backstory from Belle and the gay character
LeFou played by Josh Gad(which is handled well to be honest), it really
doesn&#x27;t bring a lot new to the table. Which is fine for some, cause why
fix what isn&#x27;t broken, but that works for and against the film. Among other live adaptations, I&#x27;d rank this below or evenly with
Cinderella, but definitely much more entertaining than Maleficent or
the Alice in Wonderland films. Odd that both Cinderella and Beauty &#x26;
the Beast are basic retellings that work for the most part, but
Maleficent and Alice in Wonderland try to be new re-imaginings that
just crumble. Perhaps Little Mermaid or Mulan might find the striking
balance of both. 6.6/10

Beast, Gaston has her thrown into the asylum carriage with her father
and rallies the villagers to follow him to the castle to slay the
Beast. Maurice and Belle escape and Belle rushes back to the castle.During the battle, Gaston abandons his companion LeFou, who sides with
the servants to fend off the villagers. Gaston attacks the Beast in his
tower, who is too depressed to fight back, but regains his will upon
seeing Belle return. He spares Gaston&#x27;s life before reuniting with
Belle. However, Gaston shoots the Beast from a bridge, but it collapses
when the castle crumbles and he falls to his death. The Beast dies as
the last petal falls and the servants become inanimate. When Belle
tearfully professes her love to him, Agathe reveals herself as the
enchantress and undoes the curse, repairing the crumbling castle and
restoring the Beast&#x27;s and servants&#x27; human forms and the villagers&#x27;
memories. The Prince and Belle host a ball for the kingdom, where they
dance happily.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>It&#x27;s the original animated movie...just higher definition of the same thing again.<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
The magical 1991 animated tale is being told again, only this time in
&#x27;live-action&#x27;. The movie stars Emma Watson as Belle who finds herself
imprisoned by a beastly creature in a cursed castle (Dan Stevens). The
two obviously at first start out at odds, but over time learn to look
past their differences and become fond of one another to the point
where they may have achieved a love that could break the spell over the
castle and everyone who inhabits it.I didn&#x27;t like it... I think the movie itself is fine. There really
isn&#x27;t that much wrong with the actual picture; it&#x27;s well made, well
directed, looks pretty, acted fine, songs (for the most part) are the
same and decent, it has a few good laughs, the CGI is mostly done
alright. My real gripes about this movie is that, aside from
approximately 15 minutes worth of material, it is exactly the same as
the 1991 animated movie of the same name. It is as close as a movie can
get to being a &#x27;shot-for-shot&#x27; remake without reaching quite to the
extent of Gus Van Sant&#x27;s &#x22;Psycho&#x22;. There isn&#x27;t any real originality to
this movie, it rips off every single scene, all the songs and lines of
dialog from the original and makes it &#x22;live- action&#x22;, which even then
it&#x27;s not really live-action since the majority of the film is done with
CGI. Granted, a lot of the CGI looks fine, but some of it looked a
little...creepy. Anyways, I can&#x27;t say that it&#x27;s a bad film but that is only because it
follows the original so closely so of course it isn&#x27;t bad. But if I
want to watch the exact same movie again then I&#x27;ll pop in the 1991
movie that feels way more genuine than this remake. I was able to feel
way more of the enchantment and charm of the cartoon than I was with
this movie. With this movie, all I was able to feel was the cynical
attitude of the producers basically saying &#x22;Well, if we make the exact
same movie again then we don&#x27;t have to think up anything new and the
audiences will be happy because they&#x27;re seeing the same movie all over
again that they could easily watch at home but this time they have to
give us money for it...Genius!&#x22; That&#x27;s what this movie feels like, it&#x27;s
lazy on the part of the writers and producers to make this movie
because they already had the movie made for them once before, all they
had to do was copy and paste. Yeah, there is a few different scenes and
songs scattered around but they either stick out like a sore thumb or
don&#x27;t make any difference to the overall story anyways so it became
pointless. This whole remake&#x27;s existence is pointless because it&#x27;s
already been done before and done way better. It&#x27;s a manufactured,
lifeless product rather than an endearing and magical love story like
before.I love the original, I really do. And I can see why people would like
this movie; like I said before, it&#x27;s not a bad film, I just have a
problem with studios being so lazy that they don&#x27;t even bother taking
the time to come up with a new or different adaptation of the material.
They&#x27;d rather ride the success of the original movie by doing the same
thing again, and it worked. And I understand that this is completely
subjective, so if that doesn&#x27;t bother you then fine. Personally, I&#x27;m
under the opinion that if a remake isn&#x27;t doing something in order to
justify its reasons for existing then it&#x27;s pointless. If a remake is
only going to do exactly what the original movie did then I&#x27;ll just
watch the original instead. Now if this movie tried putting a different
spin on things, or expanded much more on the characters, maybe taking a
unique direction, changing things up in the story that possibly could
play on expectations; then I would see a reason for this movie being
made, however as it is, it&#x27;s a lesser and longer version of a classic
Disney masterpiece. I know that I&#x27;ve been extremely harsh on the movie, but the movie
itself really is fine. Technically speaking, there isn&#x27;t that much
about it that&#x27;s necessarily bad. Emma Watson does fine in the role of
Belle, although I don&#x27;t think she has a particularly strong singing
voice. Dan Stevens I already just naturally like, he has a good on
screen presence in about everything I&#x27;ve seen him in and he does well
as the Beast. Kevin Kline I always love to see in movies, besides
&#x22;Bob&#x27;s Burgers&#x22; I don&#x27;t get to see him in much so I&#x27;m glad that he
played Maurice since he can balance kooky and lovable so easily. Luke
Evans and Josh Gad as Gaston and LeFou were pretty great actually. They
were a big reason why I laughed as much as I did while watching the
movie. Moving on. The songs from the original are still catchy and charming,
the new songs I honestly can&#x27;t remember what they sounded like; I
remember where they pop up in the story, but not so much their melodies
or lyrics...so I guess they&#x27;re...fine? Maybe? The movie looks very
pretty; the set designs and costumes are visually interesting, the
special effects are mainly done well, and there are some decently shot
sequences. So I say if you end up watching this, you&#x27;ll probably have a
good time with it and it&#x27;s fine to show to your kids for sure. If and
when I have kids though, the remake won&#x27;t be the first thing I show

the privilege of seeing that one...oh no
