<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>The whole package of everything we loved, except &#x27;the love&#x27; itself<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
The opening scenes of Beauty and the Beast are very hard to watch. This
film is such an accurate blow by blow mimic of the 1991 Oscar winner
that it even nails the timing between lines. Unfortunately this is a
live movie with real actors, and actors need timing to give convincing
performances. there is no timing here. The movie goes from one beat to
another in spectacular fashion, and never catches its breath until
halfway through the picture.The highlight is the art direction. Beauty and the beast takes the
gilded, spiralling and flowered motifs of Roccoco to the extreme, and
the beast&#x27;s castle looks like a big gold/brass jungle. The negative is
that in order to see all this in full glory, director Bill Condon pulls
his camera back so far that it becomes pretty obvious that we are in a
sound stage.Emma Watson has all the beauty of Belle, but not enough of the
charisma. She is small, composed and vulnerable, and strangely
unimpressionable. During the Be Our Guest number, she stares at the
spectacle as if she on her forty fifth take and in need of a coffee.
Her singing voice is fine, but she underplays her numbers.How much credit to give Dan Stevens for his performance of the Beast,
I&#x27;m not sure. Together with the painters/animators of his face, he does
bring some humanity but not a great deal of character. As for the other
inhabitants of the castle, The CGI bring Lumiere, Cogsworth and Mrs.
Potts to life impeccably, but makes the mistake of minimizing their
facial features, thus rendering out their character. What we get are
not humans cursed with the form of house ware, we get house ware that
talks and moves.The best part of the movie is the middle act; between the second wolves
attack and the iconic Beauty and the Beast dance scene. Condon tries to
play cupid and get Belle and the Beast to fall in love. The script
helps him by giving him some admirable new material to work with, but
he cuts his these contemplative scenes too short. As a music number
Beauty and the Beast succeeds in summoning a bit of warm and fuzzy
nostalgia. This is the only song which comes close to making you feel
like you were watching the material for the first time. Whats missing
is the chemistry.Condon stages a chaotic rendition of the fight between Gaston&#x27;s mob and
the Beast&#x27;s army of house furniture, leading to Gaston and Beast coming
face to face. Condon falls short here too by not giving them much of a
fight. He also rushes the final spectacle of the movie where the beast
is turned back into a prince. Belle watches and doesn&#x27;t even flinch.
She takes one looks at him and inherently seems to know what is going
on, then they lock lips. The transformation of all the others (back
into humans) is done with a bit more flair, not to mention humour.Minus the muscles and singing voice, Luke Evans makes for a realistic
Gaston, but it is his side kick &#x27;gay&#x27; LeFou who hogs the spotlight.
More than any individual, the imagery itself is the real star of the
show, and there is too much of it. the scenery is over lit, it goes on
forever and the camera never stays still. There is enough spectacle
that you become almost numb to it. Beauty and the Beast leaves you feeling depressed for all the people
who Disney is cheating out of they&#x27;re money. the movie itself feels
like merchandise in a Disney store. It&#x27;s a superficially enjoyable
carbon copy of something real.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Not a bad adaptation<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
It has to be said, Disney&#x27;s live action adaptations of their classic
animations haven&#x27;t really worked, &#x27;The Jungle Book&#x27; was horrendous and
the less said about the diabolical reworking of &#x27;Pete&#x27;s Dragon&#x27; the
better. However, they&#x27;ve finally managed to redeem themselves with the
newly released &#x27;Beauty And The Beast&#x27;. Apart from a few niggles, I
thought it was very good. It is easily the closest adaptation, and is
extremely faithful to the award winning 1991 animated film. Emma Watson
was magnificent as Belle and her singing voice was wonderful (I
understand she actually had some singing lessons from the original
Belle, Paige O&#x27;Hara). It is difficult to comment on Dan Stevens
portrayal of the Beast as so much was CGI, but he was suitably well
cast as the handsome Prince when he was visible on screen. Lumiere the
candelabra and Cogsworth the clock were voiced by Ewan McGregor and Sir
Ian McKellen respectively, and as much as I loved Ewan&#x27;s singing in
&#x27;Moulin Rouge&#x27;, he was hindered in this role by the awful French accent
he had to put on, which I found wavered on and off occasionally. The
teapot Mrs Potts, so perfectly voiced by Angela Lansbury in the
original, was portrayed by Emma Thompson, who I thought sounded like
she was trying to impersonate Angela instead of putting her own touch
to the character. Luke Evans stars as Gaston and in the classic
animation, Gaston was just a self-obsessed, arrogant, simple minded
villain, who&#x27;s determination to be looked on as &#x22;the best&#x22; and marry
Belle, drives him to fight the Beast out of jealousy, and was actually
depicted as a comedic character, but in this movie he is far darker
and, although retaining his narcissistic and self-centred traits, he is
much nastier and the comedic stupidity and arrogance from the original
is replaced with a far more manipulative and violent persona. The fight
between Gaston and the Beast differs too, from a simple battle of
strength and wits culminating in Gaston stabbing the Beast before
falling to his death in the animated movie, to Gaston actually shooting
the Beast a few times before eventually falling to his death. Now,
those who know me know, I don&#x27;t like change for change sake and was
very disappointed at a number of other changes too. The musical
numbers, added lyrics to the original numbers, added scenes (especially
the scene explaining the reason Belle&#x27;s mother isn&#x27;t there, which was
pretty pointless as far as I could tell). All the classic well known
songs from the original are here, but as I mentioned there are added
lyrics to some, and the lyrics in the song &#x27;Gaston&#x27; were, at times,
almost inaudible. I do understand that sometimes songs are added for
timing reasons, but there is a stunning and award winning stage
production of &#x27;Beauty and The Beast&#x27; which has added songs in it, so I
couldn&#x27;t understand why they had to write brand new songs for this
movie rather than just add a couple from the stage production,
especially the Beast&#x27;s number &#x27;If I Can&#x27;t Love Her&#x27;, which, in my
opinion, would have fitted better than the number he sings in this
movie &#x27;Evermore&#x27;. Despite the few disappointments, I do have to say
that it is a stunning movie, very well made with some excellent
performances and doesn&#x27;t stray too far from the Oscar winning original
we all know and love. Worth seeing for sure.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Beauty and the Beast Review<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
It&#x27;s a tale as old as time and a song as old as rhyme, Beauty and the
Beast. The original Disney animated movie was the first animated movie
to ever be nominated for the Best Picture category at the Academy
Awards, back in 1991. So it&#x27;s no wonder that there was a lot of
pressure to get the live-action version just right. It&#x27;s easy to
compare it to the animated movie, but the live-action version brings a
lot of new elements to the story. It provides backstory for several
characters as well as better romantic development between Belle and the
Beast. That&#x27;s all accompanied by some great and often delightful acting
performances as well as the musical songs.While the movie is basically a remake of the animated version it also
changes a few things and adds in scenes in order to tell the story
better. One new element the movies adds comes from the original fairy
tale story, and that&#x27;s Belle asking for a rose every year from her
father Maurice. The movie also adds in new scenes between Belle and the
beast that creates a better romantic connection between the two. Emma
Watson does a great job playing Belle, she brings a lot the character
beyond being warm and kind. Dan Stevens also does a good job at making
the beast sympathetic as well as caring. As for the songs. While Emma Watson does not sound like Paige O&#x27;Hara
(the voice of Belle in the cartoon) she does a wonderful job singing
the songs. Surprisingly Dan Stevens has a great singing voice and gets
an original song that is actually really good. Even though Ewan
McGregor&#x27;s French accent was not great, his version of Be Our Guest was
fantastic and different from the original. Emma Thompson does a
wonderful job as Mrs. Potts. While not copying Angela Lansbury, she
still brings warmth and care to the character. Not everything in the movie was perfect. Luke Evans is a great actor
but his version of Gaston is not as fun as he was in the cartoon. This
is evident in the song &#x22;Gaston&#x22;. Josh Gad does a great job as LaFou,
who is not quite the fool he was in the animated movie, but Gad has a
great singing voice. The other thing that was quite as well done is the
ballroom scene with the title song. The visuals didn&#x27;t feel as grand
and magical despite the setting. Some of the directing were off in a
few scenes, where the focus wasn&#x27;t clear and the angles weren&#x27;t
perfect. Some of the designs for the object characters were odd
looking, but after a while, you get used to it. However, if we stop comparing this to the animated version, this movie
is a great adaptation that has a lot to add to the story. The opening
musical &#x22;Belle&#x22; draws the audience right into the character and the
town. It sets up the story perfectly and does a great job establishing
why Belle doesn&#x27;t fit in with the town. The ending had some small
changes that were surprising and interesting. Overall this movie was
beautiful, sweet and magical, everything you want in a Disney fairy
tale movie.
<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A visually mesmerizing movie<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
First and foremost, this movie is visually stunning. From the beginning
to the end. Disney has done an amazing job of keeping everything seem
so alive, and alarmingly terrifying at times.This is a story about Belle, who is a well read town girl and wants
something more than &#x22;this provincial life&#x22;. She eventually steps into
Beast, who is a prince cursed by an enchantress. He has time to reverse
himself until the last petal of an enchanted rose falls. In the
meanwhile, Belle is continuously wooed by all-brawn-and-no-brain
Gaston, who has an evil intention of killing the Beast and forcibly
marrying Belle. Love is slowly blossoming between Belle and the Beast,
but will it be enough to break the curse?All the characters in the story have blended nicely with an amazing
cast. As I have said before, the visuals were stunning, and so were the
ballads performed throughout the musical. A 3D experience is
phenomenal, and kind of required.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A Slightly Askewed Live Action Version<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Adapting the animated classical musical into a live action musical
brought forth some memorable emotional moments but at the same time
lost the fun exaggerated, lightness captured in the cartoonish display
of several of the characters. The most prominent problem with the
updated live action movie is the casting of the real human character
Gaston whose physical presence just doesn&#x27;t capture the animated
comical snootiness of the anti-hero. The animated version had charm
whereas the live action version had to make due with a pseudo-Broadway
stage musical production and in some ways didn&#x27;t capture the dazzling
set designs along with the musical renditions found in such productions
as Sound of Music or even Mary Poppins or My Fair Lady.The live action was most wonderful when it came to the humanity of
human suffering and pain but as the same time became too edgy in its
raw, violent scenes. Oddly enough Kevin Kline while perfectly cast as
the father, wasn&#x27;t Kevin Kline enough to capture the softer and lightly
comical animated version. As for the use of song as live actions and
the voice over, which is almost second nature in animated movies, since
Les Miserable (2012) use of live singing on set, this live action
musical seemed less authentic and more acted.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A fair fairy-tale with mass appeal<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
&#x22;Would you love a monster?&#x22;, has become an increasingly moot question
in our age branded by individualism and non-conformist viewpoint, so
the answer would be: you betcha! How cool can be to tame a beast like
that? Not to mention, his monstrous front aside, there nestling a
genuine prince inside, that&#x27;s a bonus!This Disney live-action revamp of the classic fairy-tale, directed by
the workmanlike Bill Condon (DREAMGIRLS 2006 and TWILIGHT franchise,
with occasional curve-ball GODS AND MONSTERS 1998), clings firmly to
its 1991 animation in its storyboard and iconic songs, rendered
altogether with a grandiose flourish could run rings around Kenneth
Branagh&#x27;s Cinderella (2015).The preamble musters efficiency and glimpses of royal pageantry with a
more plausible premise (in the realm of magic, sky is the limit), a
selfish prince (Steven) is transformed into a monster (and his servants
into a clutter of objects) by an enchantress (Morahan), he must learn
to truly love someone and get the reciprocal affection before time is
running out, otherwise, him along with his hapless underlings will lose
humanity for keeps. Then the narrative introduces our heroine Belle
(Watson), a French village girl, who has a yen for reading and is an
inventor herself (both are inadvisable hobbyhorses for womenfolk
strait-jacketed by macho insularity), she is relentlessly pursued by
Gaston (Evans), a bumptious village war-hero who doesn&#x27;t take no for an
answer. When Belle&#x27;s father Maurice (Kline) is interned in the
monster&#x27;s castle for stealing a rose (a gift under Belle&#x27;s request),
Belle trades herself for her father, and inevitably develops a quasi-
Stockholm syndrome to her captor (with the benevolent prodding from
those anthropomorphic knick-knacks, among which a motormouth Ewan
McGregor revels in sporting a wavering French accent as a candelabra).
But when an exasperated Gaston knows about the existence of the
monster, he convenes the village mob to assail the castle, there will
only be one man standing between him and the monster, Belle is
entangled in the scramble, but her feels powerless to stop the
inevitable, until, yes, the magic moment after a poignant
humanity-dissipating corollary. What a volatile enchantress! The upgraded musical numbers are meat and potatoes to the allure of the
film, highlights are BE OUR GUEST (a cynosure garnished with the most
deliriously enchanting special effects), GASTON (Evans is so close to
snag that Hollywood leading man status for a voluntarily outed gay
actor) and Emma Thompson&#x27;s rendition of the theme song, a balm to one&#x27;s
ears, it is beggar belief that she hasn&#x27;t been cast in a musical
before!Acting wise, the film is a bog-standard family friendly fare demands
nothing taxing for its stellar cast, Watson is presentable but far from
impressive, Stevens is understandably curbed by his overwhelming
costume, even his voice is muffled as if emanated from a mask, only
Josh Gad&#x27;s LeFou adds a nice (but overtly praised) touch of gay
inclusivity.Disney&#x27;s gargantuan ambition of transposing their animation repertoire
into live-action by virtue of technique advancement, has been in full
swing and proved to be not only viable but also massively lucrative,
the only gripe is they could be more gallant in its story-telling
(different angles, re- interpretation, reflecting current perspective,
et al.), but at the same time, one cannot help but wondering does this
trend flag up an overlooking threat to the popularity of animation
filmmaking, a food for thought - when CGI anthropomorphism can
seamlessly meet the demands, what will audience (in particular,
grownups) prefer, a more realistic context or a self-conscious
other-worldly dimension?

To be more precise my rating is a 6.5 but thought I&#x27;d round it up to a
7. Well this has been a Disney remake that I, along with what I am sure
is many other people, anticipated for a very long time. I didn&#x27;t expect
too much, though: no one could top Angela Lansbury&#x27;s rendition of
Beauty and the Beast. And Emma Watson, though she does have the beauty
that is similar to Belle&#x27;s, lacks almost everything else that made
Belle the way she was. I&#x27;ll start off with a list of what I believe was bad, then end this
review on a good note. These are of course my opinions and are to be
taken with a grain of salt! (Possible spoilers ahead). The Bad: 1. Emma
Watson&#x27;s singing voice. I was informed before going into the cinema
that her voice was autotuned, but man this was autotuned to the MAX!
Some parts almost sounded a bit too robotic for my liking. 2. Ewan
McGregor. I respect him and do believe he is a fine actor, but he put
on the worst French accent I have heard. Though, his rendition of &#x22;Be
Our Guest&#x22; compensated for it. 3. When Beast transformed back into his
human self, I would have very much preferred Dan Steven&#x27;s actual look
than try and copy the cartoon&#x27;s human interpretation of the beast. 4.
The ending felt a bit too abrupt. One moment they were kissing, then
all of a sudden they were in a ballroom and everything was completely
fine. I understand that this probably had to do with pacing issues but
I do believe there was just some small transitional scene. 5. The
beast&#x27;s solo was a bit boring and not very effective. Dan Stevens has a
nice voice but I felt that it didn&#x27;t give as much of a punch as I had
anticipated. The good: 1. The visuals were absolutely stunning! I loved the cold
winter-y setting used in the castle. Absolutely gorgeous and gives a
very gloomy feel at the same time. The scene where Belle runs up the
hills as her Reprise reaches its climax was just as breathtaking in my
opinion. 2. I&#x27;m not trying to get political here but I liked the fact
that they had some dark skinned actors and actresses instead of just
all white like they did in the original cartoon. 3. It was great to see
the prologue have a more in depth story which explains some of the plot
holes present in the original film. I won&#x27;t go too in depth and let the
viewer find that out. 4. Emma Thompson did a very good job on &#x22;Beauty
and the Beast&#x22;, though my previous statement still stands that no one
could top Angela Lansbury&#x27;s rendition of it. 5. Be Our Guest was such a
delight to look at! The visuals, the choreography, the singing! It was
like watching a fireworks display. 6. I really liked Le Fou&#x27;s character
development in &#x22;The Mob Song&#x22;. They gave him much more depth than they
did in the original. I&#x27;m not just talking about the fact that they made
him a homosexual, but I liked how they didn&#x27;t make him a delusional,
devoted idiot. He knew what was right from wrong. 7. The humour was
effective. Then again I am easily entertained so I won&#x27;t go too in
depth with this point. So all in all, it was a pretty good attempt. The visuals were stunning
and most of the music was a delight to listen to, but I do believe that
the original will always be the better one. I am no film critic, just a
simple movie watcher, so like I said before: take all this with a grain
of salt!

surprised to see what a great, touching and progressive modern take
Disney was able to stamp on it. I am a big fan of the animated feature,
the story is really universal and whilst this entry does not touch the
emotional heights and the charm of the original, it offers a reminder
of what a flawless piece of storytelling this is and it graces us with
a good enough touch that managed to take me genuinely to enjoy and live
this story one more time in a different way.Whilst the songs might be the same they are always so fantastically
entertaining on their own, Bill Condon builds on that and assembles a
series of flashy musical numbers that all live beautifully on screen.
There is no fast cutting, the editing decisions in these pieces are
always warranted and the filmmakers manage to strike a perfect balance
of seeing everything unfold on screen and using the editing to enhance
the music. There are also a couple on updated or new musical numbers
and it was a great sign that they flowed with the picture fluently,
they felt genuine and didn&#x27;t play as a forced new addition.Of course the real spearhead of this production is its incredible cast
and what can one say that the list of names here cannot already do on
its own. It is just pure glee, there isn&#x27;t one half of a bad casting
decision, everybody not only fits their role, but does the perfect
amount of updating and nuance to make you buy into them as soon as they
appear on screen. Luke Evans was definitely the highlight for me, he
brought Gaston to the screen in all of his ridiculousness and irony, it
was a pleasure to see and was the high point of comedy of an already
strongly funny film.Another magical strength of the film is its CGI. There are a couple of
green screens that got under my skin because of their blatant
notability, especially considering how excellent the rest of the VFX
were. This was really state of the art work. I literally could not tell
all of the animated characters were apart from the live action ones, it
was completely seamless in a way that I think we&#x27;ve never seen done
this good before. The question never came up, there was not a single
false beat, they were absolutely perfect.However, what might be the very best part of this update is just how
modern it is. No, not only because of a gay character, which still is
such a brilliant addition because of how brilliantly they manage to
weave it into the story and adapt it into a fairy tale character.
There&#x27;s much more here, many genre conventions are broken, many
male/female stereotypes are purposefully bent and turned on their
heads, there is diversity and it so beautiful to see such an iconic
story get an adaptation that is a better representation of the human
race.Yes, there is no denying some of the ground treaded is very familiar
and I am the first to say that there still is some space for change in
this story, there still are a couple of plot point that can be updated
and because of how modern the take overall is I felt like some events
and minor character dynamics could have had a little polishing.
Technically too the film has some moments of disjointed editing and it
could have done with a little more cutting. Don&#x27;t mistake me, the two
hours never drag, but they do feel kind of unnecessary by the end, a
five to ten minute tightening could have done the job.I was initially a little cold on this film, but after realizing just
how much I enjoyed it, how it actually got to me on an emotional level
by the end and how charmed I was by the characters and their new
iterations. I have to admit that I would be happily up to rewatching
the film which was something I was doubting going in. I bumped up the
score a little because of this, I hope that a further viewing confirms
my feelings on this.

relationship with her father, Maurice. The Beasts&#x27; upbringing is more
subtly mentioned, but shows something that the original leaves out.Overall, it is a visually stunning mix of new and old. Even knowing the
story line like the back of my hand, it still managed to evoke tears
and laughter at the very same point. Nostalgic to us, or new to the
younger audience, it was brilliant.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A visually stunning and musically catchy live-action remake.<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
A tale as old as time, this Disney animated classic gets a live-action
makeover complete with singing candelabras, a crumbling castle, and a
cantankerous brute doomed to live out his days in solitude and regret.
That is, until the weird and wonderful village bookworm Belle (Emma
Watson) brings a slice of humanity into the creature&#x27;s cursed world.
But can this Beauty tame the Beast? We all know how the story plays out
yet that does nothing to dampen the exuberance and splendour on
display; each song and dance sequence is a feast of stunning
cinematography, fascinating choreography and catchy tunes. And the
recognisable theme song is, of course, still amazing. Musical numbers
alone, however, will only take the movie so far, so it&#x27;s credit to the
cast that they imbue proceedings with an additional layer of heart,
humour and interest. Watson is simply delightful as the strong-willed
and resourceful Belle, Dan Stevens is complex as the motion-captured
Beast, Luke Evans and Josh Gad are comically over-the-top as Gaston and
LeFou, and Ewan McGregor almost steals the show entirely as the
rambunctious Lumiere. There&#x27;s a couple of missteps blocking this
remake&#x27;s lofty ambition of matching the original&#x97;the runtime is
slightly too long, the sweeping shots of the castle become
repetitive&#x97;although it gets enviably close. A charming tale of romance
and redemption, Beauty and the Beast dazzles with visual opulence and
irrepressible musical energy.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>I Actually Thought This Was A Pretty Good Movie Remake.<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Honestly, there isn&#x27;t much to compare the live-action 2017 Disney
remake to the 1991 animated version at all. But, I will say this, it
actually does feel more like a live-action Broadway Musical, than it
does as a &#x22;shot-for-shot/note-for-note translation of the original&#x22;
unlike Batman: The Killing Joke (2016), Psycho (1999), and the 2014
remake of RoboCop. Now, with the characters, well..not much has
changed. I mean, it&#x27;s exactly as it was in the 1991 version, but we&#x27;re
basically given more backstories on Belle and the Beast&#x27;s parents, and
their pasts, respectively. As well as some more interactions between
the servants, Gaston and LeFou. Story-wise, pretty much the same. But,
the musical score and the songs are amazing. My only gripes are, yes,
the Beast&#x27;s design shouldn&#x27;t have been all CGI, but rather, just
practical effects, puppetry and make- up. And Belle&#x27;s iconic princess
dress in the movie...still needs more volume and honestly, they
should&#x27;ve included the glove. And lastly, I don&#x27;t get what was the big
deal about announcing that LeFou was gay in the movie. Who cares?! I
still thought he was funny and the actor did a good job portraying the
character.Overall, I&#x27;m not saying that the 2017 remake is &#x22;better&#x22; than the
original, not because of nostalgia, but because it actually does feel
more another remake to a totally incarnation of the original 1991
version aka..the Broadway musical adaptation. But, if you&#x27;re looking
for something to appeal to your 1990&#x27;s nostalgia, then go watch the
original 1991 version. You&#x27;re not really missing out on much and it&#x27;s
still a timeless classic. the 2017 remake is just another version that
will have it&#x27;s own growing fan-base, for the time being.But, through it all...I actually had fun watching this movie.8 out of 10.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Still the tale as old as time and true...<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
Emma Watson is a star. &#x22;Beauty and the Beast&#x22; may be flawed in its
excess, and is more touching and human than the animated original. Emma
Watson is radiant, beautiful, and inspired. This live action
reinvention of &#x22;Beauty and the Beast&#x22; remains the &#x22;tale as old as
time&#x22;. Watson&#x27;s Belle is rescued from killer wolves by the brave Beast played
by the tormented and noble Dan Stevens, but he is wounded and bleeding
from the attack. He fights with great strength and rage. The Beast
unexpectedly sacrifices for Belle, and lies on the ground of the wintry
forest. Belle turns about to leave and escape her imprisonment.
Gentleness melts her visage as she turns back to rescue him in return.
&#x22;Beauty and the Beast&#x22; enrolled me then.The wondrous souls of Watson and Stevens reinvent &#x22;Beauty and the
Beast&#x22;. Through astounding make-up and CGI effects, Steven&#x27;s Beast is
the towering horned majestic lion. His Beast embodies both joy and
suffering in his gentle blue eyes. Stevens accomplishes the nearly
impossible. He is a handsome man, and his Beast becomes beautiful as he
allows us to see his soul and forsaken dreams. Watson is natural beauty
with freckles on her nose. Her Belle&#x27;s innocence discovers the truth in
others, be it the Beast or the ghastly Gaston. Watson and Stevens are
beautifully sublime. With the largely familiar story-line and great songs by Alan Menken and
Hal Ashman of the original 1991 animated movie, Director Bill Condon&#x27;s
recreation is about loss, destiny, and falling in love. His spectacular
vision creates the haunting images of the wintry forest and the Beast&#x27;s
austere castle. This is a musical, and Condon wonderfully orchestrates
the song and dance. He does homage to &#x22;The Sound of Music&#x22; with Belle
singing on the hills of her village. Watson and Stevens make us believe in Belle and Beast&#x27;s love story.
There may be one too many dance numbers or introspective character
musical solos. Fortunately, they are not too distracting. Screenwriters
Stephen Chbosky and Evan Spiliotopoulos invent the poignant back
stories of Belle&#x27;s and the Beast&#x27;s deceased Mothers humanizing this
fairy tale. This is timeless tale of true love and forgiveness. The story opens as the narcissist Prince, played by believable Stevens,
callously dismisses the gifted rose from an old woman visiting his
castle. This was his test. The old woman reveals herself as the
Enchantress, played by stunning Hattie Morahan. She casts a spell upon
the Prince transforming him into the Beast and his servants into living
furniture. He shall remain the Beast until he can fall in love with
someone, who loves him back. The Prince must do so before all the
petals on the rose fall; otherwise, the curse is forever. Belle&#x27;s opening song expresses her uniqueness. She is the independent
spirit, who loves books, and has great dreams. They do not include
braggart Gaston played by talented Luke Evans, who wants to marry
Belle. She tells him, &#x22;I will never marry you.&#x22; Belle cares for her
watchmaker Father Maurice played by kind Kevin Kline. Belle&#x27;s Mother

Petals Fall as a Curse Finalizes. Beauty and the Beast (2017) Movie
review. France, 1350 disaster sweeps the streets, artist and inventor

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Only &#x27;True Love&#x27; can break the spell.<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
&#x27;Beauty and the Beast&#x27; is Disney&#x27;s take on retelling their classic 1991
animated feature in a live-action version. Introducing an all new cast
but familiar beats, and with a perfect blue-print to follow, does this
version recapture that of it&#x27;s predecessor?1. First and foremost, if you are a fan of the 1991 film, you must try
your best to see this film with an open mind. Although the plot in the
same and the story unfolds the exact same way, there are still changes
and different variations of things here and there. Everyone&#x27;s main
complaint is the look of the Beast (Dan Stevens). I would agree that he
should have more of a vicious look, but the more I thought about it, if
the original design of the beast from the animated film was translated
into live-action, he would have been too terrifying and scare the
daylights out of the younger audiences. In that sense, I can see why
Disney altered him to be more subtle in appearance for that reason.2. Alan Menken (the veteran Disney composer) returns to score this
film, and he does yet another fantastic job in recreating his original
songs for the new cast. The movie is approximately 120mins, and this
can be in part to the addition of a couple new songs as well as more
fleshed out back-stories, especially that of Belle and the Beast.
Another complaint that crossed my ears, was the casting of Ewan
McGregor as Lumiere, having been criticized for his shaky French accent
judging by the trailers. Need not worry, you completely forget about
your doubts when you see him on screen. Not only are the CGI effects
fantastic, but Lumiere completely steals the show whenever he is on
screen, especially during the &#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22; song and dance number.3. The movie however, is not without flaws. To begin with, as beautiful
as Emma Watson might be, she in no way captures the spirit of Belle.
Coming to her father&#x27;s rescue a couple times doesn&#x27;t quite sell the
point that she is as brave and courageous as she&#x27;s supposed to be. She
only skims the surface of the character without bringing much depth to
it at all. Dan Steven as the &#x27;Beast&#x27; however, shows more conviction in
his role as the cursed Prince. His persona and feeling of a tortured
soul comes closest to that of Robby Benson who voiced the Beast in the
original. Sharing (a little but not as bad) the same lack of character
depth as Emma Watson, Luke Evans (to me) feels slightly miscast as the
handsome yet egotistical Gaston.4. I applaud Bill Condon&#x27;s direction as I was blown away by every
theatrical song/dance sequences in this film. Of course the most
outstanding being the classic ballroom scene which brought tears to my
eyes. I also appreciate that the Beast finally gets to perform his own
solo song which expressed his inner struggle of both anger and
compassion. Something which was clearly missing from the animated film.
There is no arguing with Disney especially when it comes to their CGI
department, because they can do no wrong. The production design in
beyond incredible with not a hair out of place. The magic is surely
recaptured whether you admit it or not. This and &#x27;The Jungle Book&#x27;
surely stand out in Disney&#x27;s live-action line-up thus far. Fans will undoubtedly nitpick this film as much as they can simply
because the animated one is sheer perfection in their eyes. Not saying
it&#x27;s not, but it be unwise not to give this version a chance, because
it does it&#x27;s best and delivers beat for beat in a spectacular way:)
<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Beauty and the Beast<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
The 1991 original Disney cartoon was the first full-length animated
film to be nominated the Oscar for Best Picture, and following from
Alice in Wonderland, Cinderella and The Jungle Book it becomes the next
Disney classic to get the live action remake treatment, directed by
Bill Condon (Gods and Monsters, Chicago, Dreamgirls). Basically
somewhere in France, an enchantress disguised as an old beggar woman
asks a selfish prince (apparently named Adam) (Downton Abbey&#x27;s Dan
Stevens) for shelter and offers a rose in exchange, he refuses and
turns her away twice, she reveals her true beauty, but for his
arrogance she punishes the prince, transforming him into a hideous
beast, all his servants are turned into living inanimate objects, and
all memory of the kingdom is erased from the memories of the villagers.
His only way to see the outside world is through a magic mirror, and
the enchanted rose remains, to break the spell the prince must learn to
love another, and earn their love in return, before the last petal of
the rose falls, or he will be doomed to remain a beast for all time,
and the servants will become their respective objects forever. Years
later, in the village of Villeneuve, Belle (Emma Watson) is the
beautiful but unusual daughter of artist and tinkerer Maurice (Kevin
Kline), she is appalled by the arrogance and narcissism of celebrated
former soldier Gaston (Luke Evans), who seeks her hand in marriage. On
a trip to the market to sell music boxes, Maurice and his horse
Philippe get lost in the forest, following an attack by wolves, they
finds the secluded castle of the Beast, Maurice ends up locked in a
chamber as a prisoner, for attempting to steal a rose, for Belle, from
the garden. Belle realises her father is missing, she ventures into the
forest and finds the castle, the Beast confronts her, she offers
herself to take her father&#x27;s place as a prisoner, the Beast accepts
this, and Maurice is released, Belle promises her father she will find
a way to escape. Belle meets and becomes friends with the servants of
the castle, including candle stick formed Lumi&#xE8;re (Ewan McGregor),
carriage clock formed Cogsworth (Sir Ian McKellen) and teapot formed
Mrs. Potts (Emma Thompson). Wandering the castle she finds the
forbidden west wing, and the enchanted rose, the Beast is enraged, Bell
frightened runs away, the Beast saves her from an attack by the wolves,
and when he is injured during the fight, she assists him back at the
castle and nurses him back to health. Belle and the Beast form a
friendship, and the servants are convinced she may be the one to help
break the curse, the Beast allows her access to the library, filled
with hundreds of books, she may be developing feelings, but remains
uncertain due to her imprisonment. The Beast shows Belle a gift given
to him by the enchantress, a book that takes a person wherever they
want in the world, Belle uses it to take herself and the Beast to a
small house in Paris, where she used to live with her parents as an
infant, through this she learns her Mother (Zoe Rainey) died of the
plague, the Beast comforts her. Meanwhile Maurice has returned to
Villeneuve, the villagers believe him to be crazy, ranting about a
beast, but Gaston offers to help him, but reveals his true intention is
to marry Belle, Maurice refuses. Gaston leaves Maurice tied up in the
forest to die, but he is rescued by hermit Agathe (Hattie Morahan), he
returns to village and openly accuses Gaston of his crime, but Gaston
convinces the townsfolk this is more crazy ramblings, they plan to send
Maurice to an asylum. Belle and the Beast have become much closer,
sharing a romantic dance, but she discovers her father&#x27;s predicament
using the magic mirror, the Beast allows her to leave to save him, he
gives her the mirror to look back and remember him with, the Beast
realises he truly loves Belle. At Villeneuve, Belle proves Maurice&#x27;s
sanity by revealing the Beast in the mirror, Gaston realises she has
feelings for the Beast and rallies the villagers to go to the castle
and kill the Beast, Belle and Maurice are locked in a wagon. During the
ensuing fight at the castle, Gaston&#x27;s companion LeFou (Josh Gad) sides
with the servants when Gaston abandons him, the Beast is initially to
depressed to fight back, but Gaston attacks the Beast, the Beast
regains his will seeing that Belle has returned, he corners Gaston, but
spares his life. The Beast reunites with Belle, but Gaston fatally
shoots him, before falling to his death as a bridge collapses, the
Beast dies as the last rose petal falls, and all servants are turned
into their respective objects. Belle professes her love to the Beast,
Agathe watching reveals herself as the enchantress and breaks the
curse, the Beast is returned to human form, and the servants and castle
are restored to their true forms, also the memories of the villagers
are restored, with some recognising the servants, the prince and Belle
embrace, and everyone in the kingdom dances happily. Also starring
Stanley Tucci as Maestro Cadenza, Audra McDonald as Madame Garderobe,
Nathan Mack as Chip, Gugu Mbatha-Raw as Plumette, Gerard Horan as Jean
the Potter and Adrian Schiller as Monsieur D&#x27;arque. Watson is beautiful
and sings well, Stevens is good as the Beast, Evans milks the pantomime
style villain, and the supporting cast are great as well, it follows
primarily the same format, with only subtle changes, the recognisable
songs remain, including &#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22;, &#x22;Something There&#x22; and &#x22;Beauty
and the Beast&#x22;, plus great brand new songs, including the wonderful
&#x22;Evermore&#x22;, the costume design, production and special effects are
brilliant, and the love story element is believable, it may be more
style over substance, but all of the family will definitely enjoy it,
it is a most entertaining musical romantic fantasy. Very good!

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A delightful, fresh take on a well-loved classic :) *SPOILERS*<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
WARNING - THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS!First of all, there were enough differences to make it feel fresh while
sticking closely enough to the animated original to evoke the warm
fuzzies of nostalgia.That said, there were changes I liked and changes/creative choices I
didn&#x27;t like so much. To get the &#x22;bad&#x22; out of the way, I&#x27;ll cover those
first:What I didn&#x27;t like:Character designs - While some of the non-human characters had very
interesting and clever designs, with creative ways to give inanimate
objects anthropomorphic faces and features, others were far too simple.
For example, Lumierre was a golden statue of a man with candle on head
and hands compared to Cogsworth who was a cleverly designed subtly
anthropomorphic clock. The Wardrobe and Harpsichord had faces formed
from the intrinsic features of their design whereas Mrs. Potts&#x27; face is
just painted on the side! Over all, there seemed to be a lack of
cohesion as if different designers had gone off and designed one or two
characters each without comparing notes at any point.The Beast - While I loved the character, his expanded backstory and
voice, I found his design a little bland. I&#x27;ve said from the beginning
that he looked like a Buffy demon. I dunno... just looked too human.
I&#x27;d have preferred a more &#x22;bestial&#x22; face, closer to his cartoon
appearance.Gaston - They really didn&#x27;t seem to know what they wanted to do with
the character. Instead of the impulsive buffoon we saw in the original,
he was a capable military Captain, returned to his home village after
&#x22;the Wars&#x22;. Honestly, his arguments for why Belle should marry him,
while delivered with too much over-confidence, actually seemed pretty
reasonable (Basically that they were the only two who were &#x22;bigger&#x22;
than the village and should therefore be together). Felt like the early
scenes of a rom-com where Gaston would learn his lesson and Belle would
fall for him after all. He also seemed to nice in early scenes so when
he turns to pure evil, it&#x27;s a bit of a jarring switch. I did, however,
feel echoes of the love triangle between the Phantom, Christine and
Raoul from &#x22;Phantom of the Opera&#x22;, especially the more recent
productions revised to tie in better with the sequel, &#x22;Love Never
Dies&#x22;. Also, they cut out the reprise of &#x22;Gaston&#x22; where La Fou reminds
Gaston that thinking is a dangerous pastime!What I liked:La Fou&#x27;s expanded role - From his first appearance, he seemed to be a
little more than Gaston&#x27;s lackey as he had appeared in the original.
This is particularly noticeable during the tavern song &#x22;Gaston&#x22; where
he slips coins to various people in the tavern to encourage their
participation suggesting that Gaston is not quite so universally
beloved as he likes to think. He is also the one to challenge Gaston
when he feels like he is going too far. In this interpretation, I found
him quite like Bernard from &#x22;Yes, (Prime)Minister&#x22; - taking the
subordinate role but quite possibly the smartest man in the room!Plot Holes Fixed! - So many of the plot-holes in the original are
addressed. There is no reference to the rose blooming until the Beast&#x27;s
21st year - he is cursed as an adult and he has until the last petal
falls to break the curse although no time-scale is given for this.
Also, the reference to the curse having been in place for ten years in
&#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22; has been removed. Chip is seen as a human boy before the
curse so we understand that all those who are cursed become frozen in
time for however long it has been in place. Circumstantial evidence
would suggest it has been only a few years but it&#x27;s never explicitly
stated. We also learn that the curse also meant that everyone outside
the Castle would forget about it and anyone inside, explaining why the
village seems unaware of a Royal Castle within easy walking distance! A
tragic element is also added to the Beast&#x27;s back-story to explain why
the staff remain loyal to him despite it being his fault they are
cursed. The story of what happened to Belle&#x27;s mother and why her father
brought her to the &#x22;small, provincial town&#x22; was quite moving and gave
her and the Beast something else to bond over although the method by
which they discovered this seemed a little shoe-horned in and was never
mentioned again, despite how useful it might have been during later
parts of the story.I also liked the inclusion of a sub-plot from the stage musical that
the non-human characters are slowly becoming more and more the object
they have been turned into and less human (Expected them to include the
song &#x22;Human Again&#x22; but it didn&#x27;t come) and, if the curse is not lifted,
they will become permanently inanimate, simple household items. Thought
the expanded role for the Enchantress was was a nice touch.All in all, a fantastic, beautiful piece of cinema that will be loved
by fans of the original as well as newcomers who are unfamiliar with
Disney&#x27;s take on this well-loved tale :)

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A brilliant revisit to a beautiful tale from our childhoods<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
I didn&#x27;t have any expectations for this film due to the overwhelming
disappointment I felt with the previous live action adaptations of
Cinderella and The Jungle Book. It was due to this that I didn&#x27;t expect
to like this film. I was, however, pleasantly surprised.For a start, this film fixes nonsensical aspects of the original which
was a fantastic starting point &#x96; the original was never perfect so it
made sense to remake it in order to fix these imperfections. The entire
story makes more sense with the prince no longer being an
eleven-year-old when cursed; there being an explained reason for the
servants also being cursed; the fact that no one remembers the castle&#x27;s
existence; etc. There was also a more solid reason for the prince being
cursed since the audience didn&#x27;t really see much justification in the
original as there were few examples of his selfishness.The curse also comes across as more dark with the servants all slowly
losing their humanity as time goes on and being rendered inanimate
objects by the time all the petals have fallen. This introduction of
actual consequences gives an insight to the desperation of the cursed
characters as we can see how this factor leaks into their actions as
motivation, giving them more depth. It also has an emotional impact on
the audience when they resign themselves to their fate at the end of
the film. It also evokes empathy for the Beast who not only has his own
fate on his hands but the fate of everyone else in the castle &#x96; this
makes his bitterness and anger towards the beginning of the film even
more understandable due to guilt rather than just self-hate due to his
appearance as in the original. The original used this aspect to show
that Belle was making the Beast a better person, teaching him to stop
caring for his looks and be kind, but I still preferred the remake
here. Each film shows a different perspective of Beast and his
motivations (the same can be said for the servants) which is something
I love.Another great aspect would be the changes made to characters. Unlike
the original, there isn&#x27;t a single character who I felt was pointless
or underdeveloped. For example, Maurice who was portrayed as merely a
bumbling inventor in the animation had far more depth and didn&#x27;t act
like an idiot. I could also see the bond between him and Belle better.
Gaston also changed for the better, seeming more like an actual
villain. He was truly driven by his motivations whereas he didn&#x27;t seem
particularly so in the original so I was never truly convinced of him
as an evil character. Other than this, he actually did come across as
evil due to his actions more so than the original. As for Belle, I
enjoyed her character more as well as the effort they put into her
backstory. I love how they made her an inventor and showed she was a
truly capable and intelligent woman being held back by society at the
time.The most brilliant change to characters, however, was to LeFou. He was
so much better than in the original for the fact he actually had a
trait other than just being Gaston&#x27;s sidekick and you could understand
the motivations behind his actions also. I love how LeFou doesn&#x27;t just
follow along with what Gaston says with seemingly no reason and has an
actual mind of his own in that he has morals and feels guilty for what
he helped Gaston do to Maurice. The fact that LeFou seems to be in love
with Gaston gives the audience a whole new level of understanding for
his character as it&#x27;s clear he is torn between what he believes is
right and keeping the man he loves content and it shows he isn&#x27;t simply
an evil character like in the animation but a human being who is swayed
by his emotions. The film also allowed his character redemption
because, in the end, he was being used and manipulated by Gaston
through his feelings for him which caused him to be &#x27;evil&#x27;. I like the
parallels which can be drawn between the Beast&#x27;s curse and LeFou&#x27;s love
for Gaston &#x96; both made them &#x27;monsters&#x27; but there is more to them than
simply what is shown on the surface; there is good to them.What I liked most about this film is how it remained faithful to the
original, but different in all the best ways. Other than this, the new
music was absolutely beautiful and somewhat reminded me of The Phantom
of the Opera which I loved.Some scenes just didn&#x27;t need to exist though such as where Belle visits
Paris &#x96; I understand what they were trying to do, but that information
could have been delivered differently as the scene just feels out of
place (as much as I love the song). The CGI was also somewhat odd and
could have been done better.You&#x27;d think they&#x27;d be able to hear how bad the tuning is on many of the
songs. Watson&#x27;s vocals were overly auto-tuned as if they were trying to
make her sound more like the original Belle and couldn&#x27;t. Almost every
character had their vocals overly tuned at some point in the soundtrack
rendering it difficult to listen to. Some tracks are done well, but the
mixing and tuning in general just... leaves a lot to be desired. The
vocal layering wasn&#x27;t always mixed well either so it was difficult to
hear each part.As for Watson, she was the weakest link. She had some scenes where she
was amazing and other scenes where she just seemed empty in her words
and actions, like she didn&#x27;t truly believe them herself. I wish they
had cast a stronger actress and singer for this role since I felt there
was something missing from her performance.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Don&#x27;t believe the negativity<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
So, I have a bit to say. Some is about the movie, but most is about the
horrible reviews it has been getting.I&#x27;ll start with my opinion of it: I really enjoyed it. It was fun and
full of heart, like the original; not perfect, but what is? The
misfires for me came in two places: Emma Watson as Belle and the
ballroom scene. Emma Watson is a fine actress, but I&#x27;ve always felt
that her range was a bit small. Her reactions to Gaston&#x27;s advances at
the beginning of the movie are pretty much the same as her reactions to
him shooting the Beast at the end. That shouldn&#x27;t be the case. And the
ballroom scene... We&#x27;ll, the camera work and direction just felt
lacking because of the fantastic work of the original.However, that brings me to my main thrust: all of the 1-3 star reviews
here. Why? Well, after about 5 or so hours of reading, I&#x27;ve boiled it
down to a few common threads: perception of Emma&#x27;s singing, the Beast&#x27;s
CGI, and the lack of that ever elusive &#x22;charm&#x22; or &#x22;spirit&#x22; of the
original. Firstly, there are a lot of people crying &#x22;Autotune! Emma&#x27;s
been Autotuned cause she can&#x27;t sing!!&#x22; I&#x27;m not going to claim to be an
expert on Autotune. However, I have been around great singers my whole
life, and I&#x27;ll say this: if she was Autotuned, it was slight. Her
performance sounds like an above average (but not great) singer whose
vocal coach focuses on polish over emotion in the performance. Second,
the Beast&#x27;s CGI was just like Shere Khan&#x27;s in Jungle Book: magnificent
and detailed, with an emphasis on movement of hair and moisture on it.
Lastly, lack of &#x22;charm.&#x22; I thought I understood that, but when people
started talking about Bill Murray having &#x22;charm,&#x22; I was lost. Then I
realized: &#x22;charm&#x22; is subjective, unquantifiable, and is often informed
by predetermined bias; in other words, if you go looking for &#x22;charm,&#x22;
you&#x27;ll find it where you want to, and nowhere else.All of this, however, boils down even further to one shining ray of
truth: 90s kids think that their generation was the peak of culture,
and that art, music, and culture is just going downhill. That belief
leads them to look at the 1991 movie (which was fantastic) as the gold-
standard that they have an interest in maintaining. So, nothing will be
as good as it was; if this one is, then movies are getting better, not
worse, and their time wasn&#x27;t the peak of culture.Tl;Dr: Ignore the 1-3 star reviews, this movie was fan-freaking-tastic
and definitely worth the watch.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A Beauty of a Film, Magical From Start to Finish!<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
I was born a few years too late to enjoy the so-called &#x22;Disney
renaissance&#x22; films from the late 80&#x27;s and early 90&#x27;s anywhere but on
home video, but they played an important part in my childhood and
remain beloved favorites, particularly &#x22;Beauty and the Beast.&#x22; At any
age, I could appreciate the top-notch, often cinematic animation; the
witty and rousing music; the excellent voice cast; and the timeless,
moving and almost operatic story.Yet as near-perfect a film as it was, I recognized where it could be
improved; mainly the spare 84-minute runtime, which precluded giving
sufficient backstory for the main characters, as well as the
development of Belle and the Beast&#x27;s relationship beyond a mere scene
or two. It was also clear that animation, as limitless as the medium
can be, was constraining to a story with such scope and detail.
Needless to say, I was extremely excited about this live-action remake,
and am pleased to say my excitement was entirely justified.Comparisons between this film and its predecessor are inevitable and
just a nature of the beast (pun intended). Is it a cut-and-paste carbon
copy of the original? No, and nor should it be. But it isn&#x27;t a
reimagination, either. In one sentence, it&#x27;s the same film told in a
new medium, touched up very gently with influences from the whole
history of the Beauty and the Beast story. While staying true to the
original film, the small enhancements make this film something fresh
and vibrant that fans, both old and new, can enjoy.The main improvement is the generous 129-minute runtime, which allows
time for exploring the backstories of Belle and the Beast, their
burgeoning relationship (which here grows out of a mutual love of
literature and is given the extra screen-time that it deserves), and
the furthering of the development of just about every character,
elements that were either missing completely or glossed over in the
original film. Rather than slowing this film down, they help add
another dimension to the characters and overall story and make it a
more satisfying experience.The Brits lead the pack when it comes to fine acting, and the decision
made on this film to have a nearly all-British cast could not have been
better. Emma Watson is perfect as the bookish, determined Belle, and
while her soprano is more pop-sounding than that of Paige O&#x27;Hara, I
couldn&#x27;t picture anyone else but her in the role. Dan Stevens brings a
dry wit to his haunted yet equally bookish Beast, while his melancholy
baritone and piercing blue eyes recall Robby Benson&#x27;s Beast from the
original film. The chemistry between them is palpable, and provides the
beating heart necessary to carry off a story as romantic as this. While
it is hard to match the passion and anguish of Glen Keane&#x27;s animated
Beast, the double motion-capture technology employed to bring Stevens&#x27;
performance to life is a worthy effort.Luke Evans is an excellent Gaston, equal parts panache and sadism, with
a soaring heroic tenor and a handsome physique that disguises the
character&#x27;s cruel heart within. The supporting cast of luminaries like
Emma Thompson, Ewan McGregor, Ian McKellen, Audra McDonald, Kevin
Kline, Stanley Tucci, and Josh Gad are excellent in their own ways, and
bring fresh outlooks on the beloved characters without straying too far
from their animated counterparts.Alan Menken&#x27;s expanded and revised score is beautiful and thrilling,
and the new songs written with Tim Rice, while not quite up to the
level of his collaborations with Howard Ashman, work well in their
places in the film. My particular favorite is &#x22;Evermore,&#x22; sung by the
Beast in the final act. A haunting, Phantom-esque ballad, it gives
expression to the Beast&#x27;s realization that he has come to love Belle,
even as he willingly lets her go. The original songs are freshened up
with unused lyrics by Howard Ashman, and sound great when sung by this
wonderful cast.Visually, the film is a Gothic-Rococo masterpiece, with sumptuous
set-pieces and staging that would not be out of place in a golden-age
Hollywood musical. The costumes, while more period-appropriate than the
original, pay homage to the original, and strike the perfect balance
between fantasy and reality. While the animated film is in some ways
more striking, the fact that almost all of what is seen on screen was
created as a physical set and not later in CGI is quite astonishing.All together, &#x22;Beauty and the Beast&#x22; was everything I expected it to be
and more. It moved me to both laughter and tears, and as I left the
theatre I found myself wanting to see it again. What better
recommendation is there than that? For those who question this film&#x27;s very existence, I have a very simple
answer: The message contained in &#x22;Beauty and the Beast&#x22; to look beyond
appearances to see the goodness within has captivated humanity for
thousands of years, and should have expression in some medium for every
generation to enjoy and learn from. We&#x27;ve been blessed in the past
thirty years to have three masterworks: Andrew Lloyd Webber&#x27;s &#x22;The
Phantom of the Opera,&#x22; Disney&#x27;s original &#x22;Beauty and the Beast,&#x22; and
this glorious live-action remake. While it&#x27;s not a perfect film, if you
can stop quibbling over superficial details and instead consider how
well it delivers this core idea, than it is nothing short of a triumph.

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A beautifully nostalgic movie<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
The live action version of Beauty and the Beast is a remarkable movie,
with a lot of roses blooming with every scene played out. The cast was
spot on, the VFX was remarkable, the music was nothing short of
brilliant and the nostalgia was just right. This movie cannot be of
course compared to the original because as I said, it stands out from
its original material and delivers its own magic. It re-freshens the
story with an incredible soul and a heart that is beastly in its
grandeur, humor, romance and nostalgia.While some of the critics view
Disney as playing off of our nostalgic senses and giving us &#x22;a
mediocre, poorly made movie&#x22;, I disagree wholeheartedly. This movie is
more than just a nostalgic call to when the original movie came out and
how perfect it is. Yes, nostalgia plays a part in it but at the end of
the day, this new live action version stands on its own and delivers a
strong performance worthy of the effort put into making it. The
feelings I got when I first watched the original were a major part in
why I went to see the movie &#x96; and why others will too &#x96; but that&#x27;s
because nostalgia is all man needs nowadays; to remember that beauty
lies within. Kudos to the art direction team behind the sets in the
Beast&#x27;s Castle! They manage to create an architectural wonder by mixing
whimsically dizzying features to the castle with the brooding, Gothic
atmosphere that seems to loom over the snow/ice covered grounds. The
Castle is a portrayal of the darkness and despair that seem to have a
hold on the Beast&#x27;s heart, adding more depth into the structure of the
Castle. Alan Menken, who won an Oscar for the score of the original
Beauty and the Beast, was back to add his charm, expertise and soul
into the music behind the movie. For those of you who are familiar with
the music, it is pretty much the same as the original one which was
already super perfect. The songs have been executed quite nicely with
three new songs added as a tribute to the late Howard Ashman, whose
work on the Beauty and the Beast Soundtrack is just phenomenal. While
we were expecting Belle to woo us with her singing or at least Emma
Thompson with her warmth, we were delightedly surprised with Dan
Stevens&#x27; deep tenor- like vocals. This was the only scene in the entire
movie that I was dreading would be horribly executed and instead, I had
tears rolling down my cheeks with a big fat smile on my face. The
iconic yellow dress (which was altered from the original and meant to
show how different this century&#x27;s Belle is), the ballroom, the song
sung by Emma Thompson, the dance itself; it was just made perfectly.
The atmosphere of the dance, knowing that the Beast was hoping that
this would be the night he would tell her how he feels about her;
again, just perfect! Also, a huge nod to the creative team behind the
&#x22;Be Our Guest&#x22; sequence; it was magical! That scene brought tears to my
eyes as well: it was colorful, dizzyingly dazzling, filled with spirit,
laughter and brought me back to the essence of the original &#x22;Be Our
Guest&#x22;. I was singing it out loud in the movie theater.

If you loved the animated original as a child, you will be utterly

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>Promises Enchantment, But Lacks Depth<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
&#x27;Beauty and the Beast&#x27; was never my favorite Disney movie, probably
because I was your stereotypical male child who craved action scenes
and the like. As I continue to get older and look for more ways to appreciate movies,
I find myself agreeing more and more that remakes and reboots are
slowly poisoning cinema as we know it. However, I do believe there is a
*right* way to remake a movie, and turning beloved Disney cartoons into
live action adaptations so that an older audience can still appreciate
their favorite childhood stories is most definitely the right way. It
worked exceptionally well with the 2016 &#x27;The Jungle Book&#x27; (my favorite
Disney cartoon as a kid), and I was hoping it would work just as well
with &#x27;Beauty and the Beast&#x27;.For certain, the film looks amazing. The set-pieces and scenery is
extraordinary, and placing the angelic Emma Watson in the middle of it
all was perhaps the best casting decision they could have made (dare I
say this is the most gorgeous she&#x27;s ever looked?). Her singing is very
good and she&#x27;s instantly charming as Belle; no doubt she is the best
part of the film. Aside from her and Kevin Kline as Maurice, and maybe
Luke Evans as Gaston, the film&#x27;s cast failed to live up to my
expectations. Of course, it&#x27;s a problem when literally *anybody* could
have played the Beast (who, unfortunately, is the worst out of all the
animated characters. There was no emotion from the character because of
how noticeably CG he was; nothing like the animals in &#x27;The Jungle
Book&#x27;). What then happens is that on one side of the screen, you have a
heartfelt performance from Watson, but on the other side you find she
is falling in love with nothing but a video game character. The directing is an interesting thing to consider, because the film, as
you may have heard, is nearly a shot-for-shot remake of the original,
whereas &#x27;The Jungle Book&#x27; strayed from the source material here and
there. I don&#x27;t consider this a good nor a bad thing; it simply keeps me
from saying too much about Bill Condon&#x27;s directing. He proved that he
could mimic a shot perfectly, but since the film doesn&#x27;t display much
more talent than that, I hesitate to compliment or criticize it. &#x27;Beauty and the Beast&#x27;, was in the end, a disappointment. It promises
to enchant you, but really it is just showy. The beauty of its leading
actress and the world she is singing in can only take the film so far.
Even for me, an audience member who is admittedly abnormally good at
re-watching movies and still enjoying them just as much as before, I
don&#x27;t see myself revisiting the movie and not getting bored. Too bad it could not have been more. It looks fantastic, there&#x27;s just
nothing underneath. 5.5/10

<EndCommenttext> <StartTitletext>A beautifully traditional fairytale, and a triumphant return to the Disney of old<EndTitletext>  <StartCommenttext>
This is such a nice film. Taking Disney back to their roots of what
makes a good fairytale blockbuster, it&#x27;s a fantastically vibrant,
entertaining and traditional movie that&#x27;ll have you smiling from start
to finish. It&#x27;s very similar to the original film, but as far as
remakes go, Disney have done a fantastic job again, making Beauty And
The Beast an absolutely wonderful watch.I know that there&#x27;s so much adoration for the 1991 animation, but I&#x27;ve
never been its biggest fan. As nice as it is, it didn&#x27;t always have
that same Disney magic that I really love, so I wasn&#x27;t going into this
with my nostalgia goggles on, nor with any particularly high
expectations.That said, I had a great time with this movie. Above all, its
traditional feel makes it a properly enchanting watch, bringing back
the classic Disney magic of the 1950s and 90s that we haven&#x27;t really
seen anywhere on the big screen since.Unlike 2016&#x27;s The Jungle Book and 2014&#x27;s Maleficent, Beauty And The
Beast doesn&#x27;t hold back when mirroring its predecessor, but it doesn&#x27;t
make one bit of difference, simply because it&#x27;s such a pleasant and
magical film.On the one hand, fans of the original will get a wonderful burst of
nostalgia with the return of classic characters and musical numbers,
but also, the classic vibes of the film will make you remember why you
love all those old Disney movies. You may think that the fairytale
formula has been beaten into the ground, but watching this film, with
its hugely traditional feel, felt very refreshing.There&#x27;s nothing about this film that tries to be clever and different
to what we know can make such an enjoyable watch. With no dark
revisionism, no switching of roles, and no hesitation to burst into
song whenever it feels like it, Beauty And The Beast feels like the
Disney movie of old that&#x27;s been missing for so many years, and that
pleasant, colourful and fun-loving classic vibe is exactly what makes
it such a wonderful watch that will easily have you smiling ear to ear
by the end.Along with the excellent direction and writing that allow for the film
to be such a triumphant return to the classic Disney way, the
performances here are excellent, with a delightful turn from Emma
Watson as Belle, a whole host of hilarious A-listers as the furniture
at the Beast&#x27;s castle, Josh Gad&#x27;s funniest role since Frozen as Le Fou,
and a fantastically villainous performance from Luke Evans as the
dashingly evil Gaston.And on top of those performances are some stunning visuals. Although
the CGI of the Beast isn&#x27;t quite on the level of The Jungle Book, the
castle exterior is amazingly created, whilst the real-life production
design places you as firmly in a magical version of rural France as the
animated film, and the exquisite costume design adds even more to the
enchanting feel of it all.I have to say that I was really surprised by how much I enjoyed this
film, particularly given how close it is to the original, but that
doesn&#x27;t mean it&#x27;s completely problem-free. For one, as good as a lot of
the musical numbers are, they do occasionally feel a little out of the
blue. It&#x27;s not a huge issue, but the way that the songs are brought
into scenes is a little off from time to time, not to mention the fact
that the film&#x27;s second half is a lot more jam- packed with music than
the first.Another issue with the music comes in the form of some unfortunate
meddling with Emma Watson&#x27;s voice. She may not be the greatest singer
in the world, but what&#x27;s most disappointing is that her singing
sequences are heavily autotuned, and it&#x27;s very distracting,
particularly in comparison to either hiring another singer or just
letting her sing naturally.Finally, the Beast is a little bit of a disappointment. For me, the
animation managed to capture the character&#x27;s inner turmoil a lot
better, and as such make his transformation through the film even
stronger. Whilst it&#x27;s not bad here, and Dan Stevens&#x27; performance is
fine, I felt that the CGI Beast wasn&#x27;t quite the emotional presence
that I wanted him to be.Overall, however, I had a wonderful time with Beauty And The Beast. A
surprising improvement on the original in my book, but most of all a
beautiful return to the classic Disney style, with a pleasant, vibrant,
and wonderfully traditional vibe from start to finish.

because he doesn&#x27;t have much hair covering his face he seems more
human. I liked the idea that you have to judge him based on his actions
and words rather than his looks, so I feel he should looks less human.Emma Watson was a pretty good Bell here, too. She didn&#x27;t really get
anything new to do that the original didn&#x27;t, but she works extremely
well with what she&#x27;s given. Oh, and she can also sing, apparently. It&#x27;s
kind of funny that it never occurred to me until I sat down in the
theater that I had no idea if she COULD sing, but once the first song
began I was no longer worried. The curse is more fleshed out here, which is nice. We learn that the
servants will turn into ordinary appliances if the curse isn&#x27;t broken,
losing all sentience. Compared to the original where they didn&#x27;t seem
particularly unhappy with their lives, this gives it more weight. We
also learn that everybody outside the castle was made to forget they
all even existed, and see that the path to the castle was blocked by a
(possibly magical) tree.There was a subplot with the enchantress who cursed them all to begin
with returning at the end of it all, which I sort of liked. I always
found myself considering her to be the real villain of the original
film as she essentially cursed a little boy for not letting a total
stranger stay in his magnificent palace for a night, so seeing that she
made sure to show up at the end of the allotted time to see how things
played out made sense. That said, it turns out she apparently spent the
last 10 or 20 years just sorta hanging out in the local village, which
if I&#x27;m being honest is really, really dumb.There was also another subplot that literally went nowhere in which
Bell laments never having known her mother. They try to link this to
the Beast also never knowing his mother and how their fathers treated
them very differently. I was honestly worried they were going to
combine these two different subplots and shout out &#x27;SURPRISE! Bell&#x27;s
mother was the enchantress ALL ALONG!&#x27; but fortunately they didn&#x27;t do
that. It&#x27;s like finding the original had half an hour of deleted scenes
that someone just decided to edit into the movie.It is really hard to talk about the characters with this movie because
this whole thing is so close to the original in it&#x27;s script, music, and
appearance that I find myself associating some character behaviors and
motives with their original cartoon version. In the original movie
Gaston was one of my favorite Disney villains, and while he&#x27;s still fun
here, he seems less villainous. The original Gaston was an egocentric
dumb-dumb. He never really made any villainous acts until partway
through the movie when he deliberately schemed to have Bell&#x27;s father
locked away in an insane asylum unless she agrees to marry him. It&#x27;s a
calculated move to get what he wants, and he has plenty of time to turn
away but chooses not to. Here he just seems to react in the moment;
when he&#x27;s told by Bell&#x27;s father that he can&#x27;t marry her, he punches the
man out in anger and leaves him in the woods. When he&#x27;s confronted
about this by some angry townspeople, he decides to have him committed
to cover up his act. When Bell shows up and reveals that there IS a
Beast and her father is NOT crazy, Gaston then insists that she&#x27;s only
saying this because the Beast placed a curse on her to say these
things, and they have to all raid the castle to stop him from cursing
them, too. Again, it&#x27;s all reactive. It wasn&#x27;t pre-meditated, which
makes him less menacing and more...well, kinda wimpy, actually. Also, Gaston goes out like a bitch. O.G Gaston fell to his death
because he cowardly attacked the Beast&#x27;s back and was thrown from the
castle. It&#x27;s his own cowardice, dishonorable tactics, and unwillingness
to relent that leads him to get himself killed. Here he shoots at the
beast, and the bridge he&#x27;s on just sorta... breaks. I know I mostly talk about the bad things here, but that&#x27;s the whole
problem. There is a LOT to like about this movie, but unfortunately
it&#x27;s all the stuff we&#x27;ve seen before. The new and/or changed stuff is
mostly forgettable or mismanaged, but it&#x27;s largely overshadowed by the
stuff we know and love from the original. The music is still memorable,
the characters still lovable, and the story is still one of the greats.
If you liked the first one and don&#x27;t mind the fact that it&#x27;s trying
it&#x27;s damned hardest to be as close to the first as possible, then
you&#x27;ll like this one, too. If you don&#x27;t particularly care to watch the
same movie all over again, though, then just save your money.
